docTitle.titlePart:
The Country-Wife,
Theater was central to the culture of Restoration London. The restored monarch, Charles II, wanted to assert the centrality of the theater in English culture as a way of harkening back to the glory days of the Stuart dynasty in the early part of the century, when his grandfather James I had been the patron of William Shakespeare’s theatrical company, and when Ben Jonson and Inigo Jones had designed extravagant “masques” for performance at court. But Charles and his courtiers also brought back many of the norms of the Continental stage with them when they returned to power in 1660: proscenium arched, indoor playhouses with moveable scenery, for example, and actresses in the women’s parts. These changes marked a decisive break with the norms of the professional theaters of the Elizabethan era in England, where scenery was minimal to nonexistent, and where the women's parts were played by young men. During his first years in power, Charles supported the new theaters in a number of ways: he was the official patron of the company performing at the playhouse in Drury Lane where The Country Wife was first staged; he attended plays at both state-licensed playhouses frequently; he even occasionally suggested plots to dramatists. Even more important than this personal connection was an ideological alliance between the theater and the culture; this era found in the playhouse a mirror of its own highly performative character. The seventeenth and eighteenth centuries found themselves confronting an issue that has haunted culture ever since: how can we know if people are real and authentic, or if they are merely performers, acting social roles in the manner of an actor in a theater? The Country Wife is one of many literary works from this period that probes this question.
William Wycherley became a courtier in the 1670s, and his plays are set in the world of fashionable London libertines like himself. Horner, the antihero at the center of The Country Wife, is a familiar type of the period: a rake, for “rake-hell,” so called from the hellfire that such men seemed to be daring themselves to by their scandalous behavior. At the time, some observers thought that Wycherley had modeled Horner on the notorious libertine the Earl of Rochester. That might be the case, or it might simply be that Rochester was so famous and notorious in these years that he could readily be associated with any libertine figure. In any case, Horner is certainly following the libertine’s central ethical imperative--to pursue his own pleasures wherever they may lead him, and to use his “wit,” which in this period meant simply intellect, to get what he wants. Here, he advances his desire to pursue sexual relationships with the wives of men he knows by feigning impotence; men will think that he is not a threat, and women will be assured that they can conduct an affair with no damage to their reputations. What follows surprises even Horner, though, as he discovers that women--both Town women like Lady Fidget and even young Margery Pinchwife, the country wife of the title--have desires of their own, and cannot be as easily manipulated as he thought.
The Country Wife is one of the most powerful expressions of late seventeenth-century English culture, and it remained a popular play for decades in theaters throughout the English-speaking world. This play has often been classed by theater historians as a “sex comedy,” for reasons that are obvious. But Wycherley is also interested in complex social issues, such as the confrontation between the values of the town and those of the country, the male anxiety over women’s agency and autonomy, and language as the medium through which all of these social norms are expressed and fought over. Some of this concern over language is apparant in the names of the play’s characters. Some characters--Horner, Pinchwife, the Fidgets, Quack, etc.--have names reminiscent of the allegorical names in a contemporary religious text like John Bunyan’s The Pilgrim’s Progress. Such names suggest a fairly direct correspondence between a person’s name and their nature--Horner “horns in on” other relationships, for example, attempting to put the horns of the cuckold on a man guilty of being excessively controlling of his wife--such as the equally-aptly named Pinchwife.
At the same time, and going against the grain of such directness, Wycherley is concerned with how many words lend themselves to misunderstanding because they can signify different things: starting with the vulgar pun in its title that practically dares the reader not to notice it, The Country Wife includes plays on words like “honour,” “civil,” “business,” “frank,” and, most famously “china,” which accumulates multiple, increasingly sexual associations in the play’s central scene. As a general rule of thumb, while you are reading The Country Wife, if you think that you see a dirty joke or a double-entendre, you are probably not mistaken; Wycherley has almost certainly indeed put it there. Yet that free play of language that the characters revel in, and that is so productive of The Country Wife's success as a comedy, leads to a serious question. With language itself so unpredictable, so uncontrollable, Wycherley seems to be saying, how can people communicate honestly with each other? Beneath the play’s scandalous subject matter, the play seems designed to provoke serious questions about social norms, communication, and the possibilities for cohesion and harmony in his culture.

div.head: PROLOGUE, spoken by Mr Hart.
div.l: Poets like Cudgel'd Bullys, never do
At first, or second blow, submit to you;
But will provoke you still, and ne're have done,
Till you are weary first, with laying on:
The late so basted Scribler of this day,
Though he stands trembling, bids me boldly say,
What we, before most Playes are us'd to do,
For Poets out of fear, first draw on you;
In a fierce Prologue, the still Pit defie,
And e're you speak, like Castril, give the lye;
But though our Bayses Batles oft I've fought,
And with bruis'd knuckles, their dear Conquests bought;
Nay, never yet fear'd Odds upon the Stage,
In Prologue dare not Hector with the Age,
But wou'd take Quarter from your saving hands,
Though Bayse within all yielding Countermands,
Says you Confed'rate Wits no Quarter give,
Ther'fore his Play shan't ask your leave to live:
Well, let the vain rash Fop, by hussing so,
Think to obtain the better terms of you;
But we the Actors humbly will submit,
Now, and at any time, to a full Pit;
Nay, often we anticipate your rage,
And murder Poets for you, on our Stage:
We set no Guards upon our Tyring-Room,
But when with flying Colours, there you come,
We patiently you see, give up to you,
Our Poets, Virgin, nay our Matrons too.

div.head: The Country-Wife
Act 1. Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Horner To anyone attending or reading the play in this period, the name "Horner" would have immediately evoked the "horns" that traditionally were associated with cuckoldry, the practice of men having sex with the wives of other men. A man whose wife was unfaithful in this way was called a "cuckold," a term that comes from the cuckoo bird, which was believed to lay its eggs in another bird's nest. The horns were associated with male animals; to "horn" another man was to show your superior virility. , and Quack following him at a distance.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Quack A fraudulent doctor.is as fit for a Pimp, as a Midwife for a BawdThe keeper of a brothel.; they are still but in their way, both helpers of Nature.— asideA speech spoken directly to the audience, breaking the fourth wall; the idea is that audience members hear this speech, but characters on stage do not.. —— Well, my dear Doctor, hast thou done what I desired.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: I have undone you for ever with the Women, and reported you throughout the whole Town as bad as an EunuchA castrated man. , with as much trouble as if I had made you one in earnest.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But have you told all the Midwives you know, the Orange Wenches at the PlayhousesOranges sweet enough to eat out of your hand were comparatively new in England in the 1600s, and they became a popular snack-food. They were sold as snacks at theaters by young women, who became known as "orange wenches." These young women were also responsible for passing messages between playgoers, or between playgoers and performers. But some "orange wenches" were also sex workers, selling more than oranges to the single young men who made up a substantial part of the audience in this period., the City Husbands, and old Fumbling Keepers of this end of the Town, for they'l be the readiest to report it.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: I have told all the Chamber-maids, Waiting women, Tyre womenA dresser, a woman who helps others get their clothes (their "attire") on., and Old women of my acquaintance; nay, and whisper'd it as a secret to'em, and to the Whisperers of WhitehalWhitehall is the street in the Westminster where, in this period as in the modern day, much of the bureaucracy of the British government was located. And with government bureaucracy goes lots of rumor-mongering; hence the "whisperers of Whitehal," who will be sure to spread false rumors about Horner.; so that you need not doubt 'twill spread, and you will be as odious to the handsome young Women, as—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: As the small Pox.— Well—

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: And Women of this end of the Town, as—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: As the great onesThat is, the "great pox," syphilis. In short, Horner has asked Quack to spread the rumor that he is impotent as a result of syphilis. This will make women unwilling to have sex with him. The truth, of course, is that Horner is fine, and is having this rumor spread so that husbands will not be concerned about Horner's being so intimate with their wives.; nay, as their own Husbands.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: And to the City Dames as Annis-seed RobinAnnis-seed Robin, sometimes known as "Annis-seed Water Robin," was a real person in seventeenth-century London who received that nickname because they sold aniseed water, a derivative of hemlock that was used as medicine for a variety of ailments, particularly digestive issues. More to the point here, Annis-Seed Robin was reputed to be a hermaphrodite. By 1675, when this play was first staged, they were almost certainly dead, but their reputation had passed into a kind of folk memory. of filthy and contemptible memory; and they will frighten their Children with your name, especially their Females.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And cry Horner's coming to carry you away : I am only afraid 'twill not be believ'd; you told'em 'twas by an English-French disaster, and an English-French ChirurgeonA now-archaic spelling of "surgeon.", who has given me at once, not only a Cure, but an Antidote for the future, against that damn'd malady, and that worse distemper, love, and all other Womens evils.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Your late journey into France has made it the more credible, and your being here a fortnight before you appear'd in publick, looks as if you apprehended the shame, which I wonder you do not: Well I have been hired by young Gallants to bely'em t'other way; but you are the first wou'd be thought a Man unfit for Women.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Dear Mr. Doctor, let vain Rogues be contented only to be thought abler Men than they are, generally 'tis all the pleasure they have, but mine lyes another way.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: You take, methinks, a very preposterous way to it, and as a ridiculous as if we Operators in Physick"Physick" corresponds roughly to the modern idea of internal medicine; it is where we get the term "physician." In this period, the medical profession was divided by between practitioners of physick, who treated illness with medicine, and surgeons, who operated on the body with tools and sharp instruments. Surgeons also cut hair and pulled teeth. At this time, practioniors of physick would have far outranked surgeons, who were associated with more working-class or artisinal professions since they worked with their hands., shou'd put forth Bills to disparage our Medicaments, with hopes to gain Customers.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Doctor, there are Quacks in love, as well as Physick, who get but the fewer and worse Patients, for their boastings a good name is seldom got by giving it ones self, and Women no more than honour are compass'd by bragging : Come, come Doctor, the wisest Lawyer never discovers the merits of his cause till the tryal; the wealthiest Man conceals his riches, and the cunning Gamster his play; Shy Husbands and Keepers like old Rooks are not to be cheated, but by a new unpractis'd trick; false friendship will pass now no more than false dice upon'em, no, not in the City.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: There are two Ladies and a Gentleman coming up.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Pox, some unbelieving Sisters of my former acquaintance, who I am afraid, expect their sense shou'd be satisfy'd of the falsity of the report. Enter Sir Jaspar Fidget, Lady Fidget, and Mrs. Dainty Fidget. No—this formal Fool and Women!

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: His Wife and Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: My Coach breaking just now before your door Sir, I look upon as an occasional repremand to me Sir, for not kissing your hands Sir, since your coming out of France Sir; and so my disaster Sir, has been my good fortune Sir; and this is my Wife, and Sister Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: My Lady, and Sister, Sir.— Wife, this is Master Horner.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Master Horner, Husband !

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: My Lady, my Lady Fidget, Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Won't you be acquainted with her Sir? [So the report is true, I find by his coldness or aversion to the Sex; but I'll play the wag with him.] Aside. Pray salute my Wife, my Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I will kiss no Mans Wife, Sir, for him, Sir; I have taken my eternal leave, Sir, of the Sex already, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah; I'll plague him yet. aside. Not know my Wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I do know your Wife, Sir, she's a Woman, Sir, and consequently a Monster, Sir, a greater Monster than a Husband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: A Husband; how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So, Sir; but I make no more Cuckholds, Sir. makes horns.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah, Mercury, Mercury.Mercury was one of the most common treatments for syphilis and other venereal diseases in this period; it could be ingested like a medicine, or rubbed over the body. The so-called cure was sometimes as bad as the disease. Sir Jaspar is joking to himself that Horner has probably taken mercury to cure his rumored bout with syphilis, and is therefore impotent.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Pray, Sir Jaspar, let us be gone from this rude fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dainty
sp.l: Who, by his breeding, wou'd think, he had ever been in France?

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l:
Foh, he's but too much a French fellow, such as hate Women of quality and virtue, for their love to their
Husbands, Sr. Jaspar; a Woman is hated by'em as much for loving her Husband, as for loving their Money: But pray, let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: You do well, Madam, for I have nothing that you came for: I have brought over not so much as a Bawdy Picture, new Postures, nor the second Part of the Escole des FillesThat is, Horner is saying that he is so disinterested in sex now that he has not bothered to bring back any pornography from France, such as erotic pictures, "postures" in the form of books outlining sexual positions, or copies of the "Escole des Filles", or "The Girl's School," a French erotic work first published in 1655 that was translated into English as "The School of Venus." ; Nor—

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Hold for shame, Sir; what d'y mean? you'l ruine your self for ever with the Sex— apart to Horner.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah, he hates Women perfectly I find.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: What pitty 'tis he shou'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Ay, he's a base rude Fellow for't; but affectation makes not a Woman more odious to them, than Virtue.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Because your Virtue is your greatest affectation, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: How, you sawcy Fellow, wou'd you wrong my honour?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: If I cou'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: How d'y mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah, no he can't wrong your Ladyships honour, upon my honour; he poor Man—hark you in your ear—a meer Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: O filthy French Beast, soh, soh; why do we stay? let's be gone; I can't endure the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Stay, but till the Chairs come, they'l be here presently.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nor can I stay longer; 'tis—let me see, a quarter and a half quarter of a minute past elevenPocket watches with minute hands were a very new (and expensive) piece of high tech in 1675. Up until that point, watches would only have had an hour hand. Jaspar is showing off his fancy new gadget.; the Council will be sate, I must away: business must be preferr'd always before Love and Ceremony with the wise Mr. Horner.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And the Impotent Sir Jaspar

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, ay, the impotent Master Horner, hah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: What leave us with a filthy Man alone in his lodgings?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l:
He's an innocent Man now, you know; pray stay, I'll hasten the Chaires That is, a sedan chair, an enclosed chair for hire that would be carried on the shoulders of two men. In this era, traveling by chair was an expensive way to get around London, but in a period when the streets would have been pretty muddy and filthy, it was the best way to travel in style and also keep your clothes from getting dirty.to you. —Mr. Horner your Servant,
shou'd be glad to see you at my house; pray, come and dine with me, and play at Cards with my Wife after dinner, you are fit for Women at that game; yet hah, ha—['Tis as much a Husbands prudence to provide innocent diversion for a Wife, as to hinder her unlawful pleasures; and he had better employ her, than let her employ her self. Aside. Farewel. Exit Sir Jaspar

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Your Servant Sr. Jaspar

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I will not stay with him, foh—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, Madam, I beseech you stay, if it be but to see, I can be as civil to Ladies yet, as they wou'd desire.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, no, foh, you cannot be civil to Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: You as civil as Ladies wou'd desire.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, no, no, foh, foh, foh. Exeunt Lady Fidget and Dainty.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Now I think, I, or you your self rather, have done your business with the Women.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Thou art an Ass, don't you see already upon the report and my carriage, this grave Man of business leaves his Wife in my lodgings, invites me to his house and wife, who before wou'd not be acquainted with me out of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Nay, by this means you may be the more acquainted with the Husbands, but the less with the Wives.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Let me alone, if I can but abuse the Husbands, I'll soon disabuse the Wives: Stay—I'll reckon you up the advantages, I am like to have by my Stratagem: First, I shall be rid of all my old Acquaintances, the most insatiable sorts of DunsCreditors showing up with unpaid bills. , that invade our Lodgings in a morning: And next, to the pleasure of making a New Mistriss is that of being rid of an old One, and of all old Debts; Love when it comes to be so, is paid the most unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Well, you may be so rid of your old Acquaintances; but how will you get any new Ones?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
Doctor, thou wilt never make a good Chymist, thou art so incredulous and impatient; ask but all the young Fellows of the Town, if they do not loose more time like Huntsmen, in starting the game, than in running it down; one
knows not where to find'em, who will, or will not; Women of Quality are so civil, you can hardly distinguish love from good breeding, and a Man is often mistaken; but now I can be sure, she that shews an aversion to me loves the sport, as those Women that are gone, whom I warrant to be right: And then the next thing, is your Women of Honour, as you call'em, are only chary of their reputations, not their Persons, and 'tis scandal they wou'd avoid, not Men: Now may I have, by the reputation of an Eunuch, the Priviledges of One; and be seen in a Ladies Chamber, in a morning as early as her Husband; kiss Virgins before their Parents, or Lovers; and may be in short the Pas par toutFrench for "pass through everything" or "pass everywhere": a pass key or master-key that opens every lock. Horner is saying that he will now be able to go into every house he wants. of the Town. Now Doctor.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Nay, now you shall be the Doctor; and your Process is so new, that we do not know but it may succeed.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Not so new neither, Probatum estLatin for "it is proven." Doctor.

sp.speaker: Quack
sp.l: Well, I wish you luck and many Patients whil'st I go to mine. Exit Quack. Enter Harcourt, and Dorilant to Horner.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Come, your appearance at the Play yesterday, has I hope hardned you for the future against the Womens contempt, and the Mens raillery; and now you'l abroad as you were wont.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Did I not bear it bravely?

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: With a most Theatrical impudence; nay more than the Orange-wenches shew there, or a drunken vizard In this period, it had become fashionable for women to black "vizard masks" in public, disguising their identity and creating an aura of mystery. They were worn by respectable women, but a women known *as* a "Vizard Mask" was likely to be a sex worker. Mask, or a great belly'd Actress; nay, or the most impudent of Creatures, and ill Poet; or what is yet more impudent, a secondhand Critick.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But what say the Ladies, have they no pitty?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: What Ladies? the vizard Masques you know never pitty a Man when all's gone, though in their Service.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: And for the Women in the boxes, you'd never pitty them, when 'twas in your power.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: They say 'tis pitty, but all that deal with common Women shou'd be serv'd so.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l:
Nay, I dare swear, they won't admit you to play at
Cards with them, go to Plays with'em, or do the little duties which other Shadows of men, are wont to do for'em.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Who do you call Shadows of Men?

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Half Men.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What Boyes?

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Ay your old Boyes, old beaux Garcons, who like superannuated Stallions are suffer'd to run, feed, and whinney with the Mares as long as they live, though they can do nothing else.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well a Pox on love and wenching, Women serve but to keep a Man from better Company; though I can't enjoy them, I shall you the more: good fellowship and friendship, are lasting, rational and manly pleasures.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: For all that give me some of those pleasures, you call effeminate too, they help to relish one another.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: They disturb one another.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, Mistresses are like Books; if you pore upon them too much, they doze you, and make you unfit for Company; but if us'd discreetly, you are the fitter for conversation by'em.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: A Mistress shou'd be like a little Country retreat near the Town, not to dwell in constantly, but only for a night and away; to tast the Town the better when a Man returns.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I tell you, 'tis as hard to be a good Fellow, a good Friend, and a Lover of Women, as 'tis to be a good Fellow, a good Friend, and a Lover of Money : You cannot follow both, then choose your side; Wine gives you liberty, Love takes it away.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Gad, he's in the right on't.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Wine gives you joy, Love grief and tortures; besides the Chirurgeon's Wine makes us witty, Love only Sots: Wine makes us sleep, Love breaks it.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: By the World he has reason, Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Wine makes—

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Ay, Wine makes us—makes us Princes, Love makes us Beggars, poor Rogues, y gad—and Wine—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So, there's one converted.—No, no, Love and Wine, Oil and Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I grant it; Love will still be uppermost.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Come, for my part I will have only those glorious, manly pleasures of being very drunk, and very slovenly. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Mr. Sparkish is below, Sir.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: What, my dear Friend! a Rogue that is fond of me, only I think for abusing him.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: No, he can no more think the Men laugh at him, than that Women jilt him, his opinion of himself is so good.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well, there's another pleasure by drinking, I thought not of; I shall loose his acquaintance, because he cannot drink; and you know 'tis a very hard thing to be rid of him, for he's one of those nauseous offerers at wit, who like the worst Fidlers run themselves into all Companies.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: One, that by being in the Company of Men of sense wou'd pass for one.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And may so to the short-sighted World, as a false Jewel amongst true ones, is not discern'd at a distance; his Company is as troublesome to us, as a Cuckholds, when you have a mind to his Wife's.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, the Rogue will not let us enjoy one another, but ravishes our conversation, though he signifies no more to't, than Sir Martin Mar-all's"Martin Mar-all" is the lead character in a popular contemporary comedy of the same name, adapted by John Dryden from a French play by Moliere. As his name suggests, Martin Mar-all is a bit of a fool. In the scene referred to here, he mimes singing while playing a lute to seduce a woman, but the voice is actually coming from his servant offstage; the servant stops, but Mar-all continues miming, thereby messing up the entire plan. gaping, and auker'dawkwardthrumming upon the Lute, does to his Man's Voice, and Musick.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: And to pass for a wit in Town, shewes himself a fool every night to us, that are guilty of the plot.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Such wits as he are, to a Company of reasonable Men, like Rooks to the GamestersA rook is someone who cheats at cards, so a "rook" to a group of ordinary "gamesters" would be who is ruining the game for everyone else involved, who only fill a room at the Table, but are so far from contributing to the play, that they only serve to spoil the fancy of those that do.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Nay, they are us'd like Rooks too, snub'd, check'd, and abus'd; yet the Rogues will hang on.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Pox on'em, and all that force Nature, and wou'd be still what she forbids'em; Affectation is her greatest Monster.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Most Men are the contraries to that they wou'd seem; your bully you see, is a Coward with a long Sword; the little humbly fawning Physician with his Ebony cane, is he that destroys Men.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: The Usurer, a poor Rogue, possess'd of moldy Bonds, and Mortgages; and we they call Spend-thrifts, are only wealthy, who lay out his money upon daily new purchases of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, your errantest cheat, is your Trustee, or Executor; your jealous Man, the greatest Cuckhold; your Church-man, the greatest Atheist; and your noisy pert Rogue of a wit, the greatest Fop A man who was overly concerned with his appearance to the point of being ridiculous. The figure of the "fop" was a frequent butt of jokes in this period., dullest Ass, and worst Company as you shall see: For here he comes. Enter Sparkish to them.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How is't, Sparks, how is't? Well Faith, Harry, I must railly to banter with in a teasing or mocking sensethee a little, ha, ha, ha, upon the report in Town of thee, ha, ha, ha, I can't hold y Faith; shall I speak?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Yes, but you'l be so bitter then.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Honest Dick and Franck here shall answer for me, I will not be extream bitter by the Universe.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: We will be bound in ten thousand pound Bond, he shall not be bitter at all.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Nor sharp, nor sweet.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What, not down right insipid?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay then, since you are so brisk, and provoke me, take what follows; you must know, I was discoursing and raillying with some Ladies yesterday, and they hapned to talk of the fine new signes in Town.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Very fine Ladies I believe.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Said I, I know where the best new sign is. Where, says one of the Ladies? In Covent-Garden, I reply'd. Said another, In what street? In Russel-street Russell Street, where Horner lives, is right in the middle of the Covent Garden neighborhood, close to the playhouses, and a very short walk from theater where this play was first staged., answered I. Lord says another, I'm sure there was, said I again, and it came out of France, and has been there a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: A Pox I can hear no more, prethee.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No hear him out; let him tune his crowd a while.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: The worst Musick the greatest preparation.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay faith, I'll make you laugh. It cannot be, says a third Lady. Yes, yes, quoth I again. Says a fourth Lady,

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Look to't, we'l have no more Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No.—then mark, mark, now, said I to the fourth, did you never see Mr. Horner; he lodges in Russel-street, and he's a sign of a Man, you know, since he came out of France, heh, hah, he.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But the Divel take me, if thine be the sign of a jest.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: With that they all fell a laughing, till they bepiss'd themselves; what, but it do's not move you, methinks? well see one had as good go to Law without a witness, as break a jest without a laugher on ones side.—Come, come Sparks, but where do we dine, I have left at Whitehal an Earl to dine with you.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Why, I thought thou hadst lov'd a Man with a title better, than a Suit with a French trimming to't.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Go, to him again.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No, Sir, a wit to me is the greatest title in the World.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But go dine with your Earl, Sir, he may be exceptious; aggrieved, in the sense of "taking exception to"we are your Friends, and will not take it ill to be left, I do assure you.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Nay, faith he shall go to him.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: We'l thrust you out, if you wo'not, what disappoint any Body for us.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, dear Gentlemen hear me.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, no, Sir, by no means; pray go Sir.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Why, dear Rogues. They all thrust him out of the room. Sparkish returns.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: But, Sparks, pray hear me; what d'ye think I'll eat then with gay shallow Fops, and silent Coxcombs? I think wit as necessary at dinner as a glass of good wine, and that's the reason I never have any stomach when I eat alone.—Come, but where do we dine?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ev'n where you will.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: At Chateline's. Chateline's, or, in some accounts, Chatelaine's was a popular French restaurant in the Covent Garden neighborhood. The "Cock" and the "Dog and Partidge" are also local eating places.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Yes, if you will.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Or at the Cock.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Yes, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Or at the Dog and Partridge.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, if you have mind to't, for we shall dine at neither.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, with your fooling we shall loose the new Play; and I wou'd no more miss seing a new Play the first day, than I wou'd miss setting in the wits Row; therefore I'll go fetch my Mistriss and away.

div.stage: Manent Horner, Harcourt, Dorilant; Enter to them Mr. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Who have we here, Pinchwife?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife.
sp.l: Gentlemen, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well, Jack, by thy long absence from the Town, the grumness of thy countenance, and the slovenlyness of thy habit; I shou'd give thee joy, shou'd I not, of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: [Death does he know I'm married too? I thought to have conceal'd it from him at least.] Aside. My long stay in the Country will excuse my dress, and I have a suit of Law, that brings me up to Town, that puts me out of humour; besides I must give Sparkish tomorrow five thousand pound to lye with my Sister.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, you Country Gentlemen rather than not purchase, will buy any thing, and he is a crackt title, if we may quibble: Well, but am I to give thee joy, I heard thou wert marry'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, the next thing that is to be heard, is thou'rt a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Insupportable name. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But I did not expect Marriage from such a Whoremaster as you, one that knew the Town so much, and Women so well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why, I have marry'd no London Wife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Pshaw, that's all one, that grave circumspection in marrying a Country Wife, is like refusing a deceitful pamper'd Smithfield Jade, to go and be cheated by a Friend in the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: A Pox on him and his Simile. Aside. At least we are a little surer of the breed there, know what her keeping has been, whether foyl'd or unsound.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
Come, come, I have known a clapcase of venereal disease, most typically gonorrhea gotten in Wales and
there are Cozens, Justices, Clarks, and Chaplains in the Country, I won't say Coach-men, but she's handsome and young.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife.
sp.l: I'll answer as I shou'd do. Aside. No, no, she has no beauty, but her youth; no attraction, but her modesty, wholesome, homely, and huswifely, that's all.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: He talks as like a Grasier as he looks.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: She's too auker'd, ill favour'd, and silly to bring to Town.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Then methinks you shou'd bring her, to be taught breeding.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: To be taught; no, Sir, I thank you, good Wives, and private Souldiers shou'd be ignorant.—[I'll keep her from your instructions, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: The Rogue is as jealous, as if his wife were not ignorant. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, if she be ill favour'd, there will be less danger here for you, than by leaving her in the Country; we have such variety of dainties, that we are seldom hungry.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: But they have alwayes coarse, constant, swinging stomachs in the Country.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Foul Feeders indeed.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: And your Hospitality is great there.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Open house, every Man's welcome.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: So, so, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But prethee, why woud'st thou marry her? if she be ugly, ill bred, and silly, she must be rich then.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: As rich as if she brought me twenty thousand pound out of this Town; for she'l be as sure not to spend her moderate portion, as a London Baggage wou'd be to spend hers, let it be what it wou'd; so 'tis all one: then because shes ugly, she's the likelyer to be my own; and being ill bred, she'l hate conversation; and since silly and innocent, will not know the difference betwixt a Man of one and twenty, and one of forty

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
Nine—to my knowledge; but if she be silly, she'l expect as much from a Man of forty nine, as from him of one and twenty: But methinks wit is more necessary than beauty,
and I think no young Woman ugly that has it, and no handsome Woman agreable without it.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis my maxime, he's a Fool that marrys, but he's a greater that does not marry a Fool; what is wit in a Wife good for, but to make a Man a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Yes, to keep it from his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: A Fool cannot contrive to make her husband a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, but she'l club with a Man that can; and what is worse, if she cannot make her Husband a Cuckold, she'l make him jealous, and pass for one, and then 'tis all one.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, well, I'll take care for one, my Wife shall make me no Cuckold, though she had your help Mr. Horner; I understand the Town, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: His help! Aside.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: He's come newly to Town it seems, and has not heard how things are with him. Aside

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But tell me, has Marriage cured thee of whoring, which it seldom does.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: 'Tis more than age can do.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, the word is, I'll marry and live honest; but a Marriage vow is like a penitent Gamesters Oath, and entring into Bonds, and penalties to stint himself to such a particular small sum at play for the future, which makes him but the more eager, and not being able to hold out, looses his Money again, and his forfeit to boot.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Ay, ay, a Gamester will be a Gamester, whilst his Money lasts; and a Whoremaster, whilst his vigour.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Nay, I have known'em, when they are broke and can loose no more, keep a fumbling with the Box in their hands to fool with only, and hinder other Gamesters.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: That had wherewithal to make lusty stakes.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, you may laugh at me, but you shall never lye with my Wife, I know the Town.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But prethee, was not the way you were in better, is not keeping better than Marriage?

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: A Pox on't, the Jades wou'd jilt me, I cou'd never keep a Whore to my self.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So then you only marry'd to keep a Whore to your self; well, but let me tell you, Women, as you say, are like Souldiers made constant and loyal by good pay, rather than by Oaths and Covenants, therefore I'd advise my Friends to keep rather than marry; since too I find by your example, it does not serve ones turn, for I saw you yesterday in the eighteen penny place with a pretty Country-wench.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: How the Divel, did he see my Wife then? I sate there that she might not be seen; but she shall never go to a play again. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What dost thou blush at nine and forty, for having been seen with a Wench?

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: No Faith, I warrant 'twas his Wife; for Men are now there out of sight, for he's a cunning Rogue, and understands the Town.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: He blushes, then 'twas his Wife; for Men are now more ashamed to be seen with them in publick, than with a Wench.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Hell and damnation, I'm undone, since Horner has seen her, and they know 'twas she. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But prethee, was it thy Wife? She was exceedingly pretty; I was in love with her at that distance.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: You are like never to be nearer to her. Your Servant Gentleman. Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, prethee stay.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: I cannot, I will not.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Come you shall dine with us.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: I have din'd already.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Come, I know thou hast not; I'll treat thee dear Rogue, sha't spend none of thy Hampshire Money to day.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Treat me; so he uses me already like his Cuckold. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: I must, I have business at home. Exit Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: To beat his Wife, he's as jealous of her, as a Cheapside Husband of a Covent-garden Wife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, tis as hard to find an old Whoremaster without jealousy and the gout, as a young one without fear or the Pox.
As Gout in Age, from Pox in Youth proceeds;
So Wenching past, then jealousy succeeds:
The worst disease that Love and Wenching breeds.

div.stage: Mrs. Margery Pinchwife, and Alithea: Mr. Pinchwife peeping behind at the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray, Sister, where are the best Fields and Woods, to walk in in London?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: A pretty Question; why, Sister! Mulberry Garden and St. James's Park; and for close walks the New Exchange.,Mulberry Gardens, so called because of mulberry trees that had been planted there decades earlier, were located about where Buckingham Palace is now. St. James's Park is a nearby royal park. The New Exchange was an enclosed shopping arcade on the Strand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray, Sister, tell me why my Husband looks so grum here in Town? and keeps me up so close, and will not let me go a walking, nor let me wear my best Gown yesterday?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: O he's jealous, Sister.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Jealous, what's that?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: He's afraid you shou'd love another Man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: How shou'd he be afraid of my loving another man, when he will not let me see any but himself.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Did he not carry you yesterday to a Play?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, but we sate amongst ugly People, he wou'd not let me come near the Gentry, who sate under us, so that I cou'd not see'em : He told me, none but naughty Women sate there, whom they tous'd and mous'd; but I wou'd have ventur'd for all that.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: But how did you like the Play?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Indeed I was aweary of the Play, but I lik'd hugeously the Actors; they are the goodlyest proper'st Men, Sister.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: O but you must not like the Actors, Sister.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, how shou'd I help it, Sister? Pray, Sister, when my Husband comes in, will you ask leave for me to go a walking?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: A walking, hah, ha; Lord, a Country Gentlewomans leasure is the drudgery of a foot-post; and she requires as much airing as her Husbands Horses. Aside. Enter Mr. Pinchwife to them. But here comes your Husband; I'll ask, though I'm sure he'l not grant it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: He says he won't let me go abroad, for fear of catching the Pox.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Fye, the small Pox you shou'd say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Oh my dear, dear Bud, welcome home; why dost thou look so fropish, who has nanger'd thee?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Your a Fool. Mrs. Pinchwife goes aside, & cryes.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Faith so she is, for crying for no fault, poor tender Creature!

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What you wou'd have her as impudent as your self, as errant a Jilflirt, a gadder, a Magpy, and to say all a meer notorious Town-Woman?

sp.speaker: Alit.
sp.l: Brother, you are my only Censurer; and the honour of your Family shall sooner suffer in your Wife there, than in me, though I take the innocent liberty of the Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Hark you Mistriss, do not talk so before my Wife, the innocent liberty of the Town!

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Why, pray, who boasts of any intrigue with me? what Lampoon has made my name notorious? what ill Women frequent my Lodgings? I keep no Company with any Women of scandalous reputations.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, you keep the Men of scandalous reputations Company.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Where? wou'd you not have me civil? answer'em in a Box at the Plays? in the drawing room at Whitehal? in St. James's Park? Mulberry-garden? or—

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Hold, hold, do not teach my Wife, where the Men are to be found; I believe she's the worse for your Town
documents already; I bid you keep her in ignorance as I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Indeed be not angry with her Bud, she will tell me nothing of the Town, though I ask her a thousand times a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Then you are very inquisitive to know, I find?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Not I indeed, Dear, I hate London; our Placehouse in the Country is worth a thousand of't, wou'd I were there again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So you shall I warrant; but were you not talking of Plays, and Players, when I came in? you are her encourager in such discourses.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: No indeed, Dear, she chid me just now for liking the Player Men.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, if she be so innocent as to own to me her likeing them, there is no hurt in't— Aside. Come my poor Rogue, but thou lik'st none better then me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes indeed, but I do, the Player Men are finer Folks.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But you love none better then me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: You are mine own Dear Bud, and I know you, I hate a Stranger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, my Dear, you must love me only, and not be like the naughty Town Women, who only hate their Husbands, and love every Man else, love Plays, Visits, fine Coaches, fine Cloaths, Fidles, Balls, Treates, and so lead a wicked Town-life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, if to enjoy all these things be a Town-life, London is not so bad a place, Dear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How! if you love me, you must hate London.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: The Fool has forbid me discovering to her the pleasures of the Town, and he is now setting her a gog upon them himself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: But, Husband, do the Town-women love the Player Men too?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why, you do not, I hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, no, Bud; but why have we no Player-men in the Country?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ha—Mrs. Minx, ask me no more to go to a Play.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, why, Love? I did not care for going; but when you forbid me, you make me as't were desire it.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: So 'twill be in other things, I warrant. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray, let me go to a Play, Dear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Hold your Peace, I wo'not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why, Love?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why, I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Nay, if he tell her, she'l give him more cause to forbid her that place. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray, why, Dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: First, you like the Actors, and the Gallants may like you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What, a homely Country Girl? no Bud, no body will like me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I tell you, yes, they may.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, no, you jest—I won't believe you, I will go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I tell you then, that one of the lewdest Fellows in Town, who saw you there, told me he was in love with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Indeed! who, who, pray, who wast?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I've gone too far, and slipt before I was aware; how overjoy'd she is! Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Was it any Hampshire Gallant, any of our Neighbours? I promise you, I am beholding to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I promise you, you lye; for he wou'd but ruin you, as he has done hundreds: he has no other love for Women, but that, such as he, look upon Women like BasilicksA mythical serpent-creature that kills by looking at you., but to destroy'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, but if he loves me, why shou'd he ruin me? answer me to that: methinks he shou'd not, I wou'd do him no harm.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Hah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
'Tis very well; but I'll keep him from doing you any harm, or me either.
Enter Sparkish and Harcourt. But here comes Company, get you in, get you in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: But pray, Husband, is he a pretty Gentleman, that loves me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: In baggage, in. Thrusts her in: shuts the door. What all the lewd Libertines of the Town brought to my Lodging, by this easie Coxcomb! S'death I'll not suffer it.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Here Harcourt, do you approve my choice? Dear, little Rogue, I told you, I'd bring you acquainted with all my Friends, the wits, and— Harcourt salutes her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, they shall know her, as well as you your self will, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: This is one of those, my pretty Rogue, that are to dance at your wedding to morrow; and him you must bid welcome ever, to what you and I have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Monstrous!— Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Harcourt how dost thou like her, Faith? Nay, Dear, do not look down; I should hate to have a wife of mine out of countenance at any thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Wonderful!

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Tell me, I say, Harcourt, how dost thou like her? thou hast star'd upon her enough, to resolve me.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: So infinitely well, that I cou'd wish I had a Mistriss too, that might differ from her in nothing, but her love and engagement to you.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Sir, Master Sparkish has often told me, that his Acquaintance were all Wits and Raillieurs, and now I find it.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No, by the Universe, Madam, he does not railly now; you may believe him: I do assure you, he is the honestest, worthyest, true hearted Gentleman— A man of such perfect honour, he wou'd say nothing to a Lady, he does not mean.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Praising another Man to Mistriss!

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Sir, you are so beyond expectation obliging, that—

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, I gad, I am sure you do admire her extreamly, I see't in your eyes.— He does admire you Madam.— By the World, don't you?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Yes, above the World, or, the most glorious part of it, her whole Sex; and till now I never thought I shou'd have envy'd you, or any Man about to marry, but you have the best excuse for Marriage I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Nay, now, Sir, I'm satisfied you are of the Society of the Wits, and Raillieurs, since you cannot spare your Friend, even when he is but too civil to you; but the surest sign is, since you are an Enemy to Marriage, for that I hear you hate as much as business or bad Wine.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Truly, Madam, I never was an Enemy to Marriage, till now, because Marriage was never an Enemy to me before.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: But why, Sir, is Marriage an Enemy to you now? Because it robs you of your Friend here; for you look upon a Friend married as one gone into a Monastery, that is dead to the World.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: 'Tis indeed, because you marry him; I see Madam, you can guess my meaning: I do confess heartily and openly, I wish it were in my power to break the Match, by Heavens I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Poor Franck!

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Wou'd you be so unkind to me?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, no, 'tis not because I wou'd be unkind to you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Poor Franck, no gad, 'tis only his kindness to me.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Great kindness to you indeed; insensible Fop, let a Man make love to his Wife to his face. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come dear Franck, for all my Wife there that shall be, thou shalt enjoy me sometimes dear Rogue; by my honour, we Men of wit condole for our deceased Brother in Marriage, as much as for one dead in earnest: I think that was prettily said of me, ha Harcourt? —But come Franck, be not not melancholy for me.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, I assure you I am not melancholy for you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Prethee, Frank, dost think my Wife that shall be there a fine Person.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I cou'd gaze upon her, till I became as blind as you are.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How, as I am! how!

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Because you are a Lover, and true Lovers are blind, stockblind.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: True, true; but by the World, she has wit too, as well as beauty: go, go with her into a corner, and trye if she has wit, talk to her any thing, she's bashful before me.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Indeed if a Woman wants wit in a corner, she has it no where.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Sir, you dispose of me a little before your time.— Aside to Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay nay, Madam let me have an earnest of your obedience, or—go, go, Madam— Harcourt courts Alithea aside.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: How, Sir, if you are not concern'd for the honour of a Wife, I am for that of a Sister; he shall not debauch her: be a Pander to your own Wife, bring Men to her, let'em make love before your face, thrust'em into a corner together, then leav'em in private! is this your Town wit and conduct?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Hah, ha, ha, a silly wise Rogue, wou'd make one laugh more then a stark Fool, hah, ha: I shall burst. Nay, you shall not disturb'em; I'll vex thee, by the World. Struggles with Pinch. to keep him from Harc. and Alithea

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: The writings are drawn, Sir, settlements made; 'tis too late, Sir, and past all revocation.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Then so is my death.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I wou'd not be unjust to him.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Then why to me so?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I have no obligation to you.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: My love.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I had this before.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: You never had it; he wants you see jealousie, the only infallible sign of it.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Love proceeds from esteem; he cannot distrust my virtue, besides he loves me, or he wou'd not marry me.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l:
Marrying you, is no more sign of his love, then bribing your Woman, that he may marry you, is a sign of his generosity: Marriage is rather a sign of interest, then love; and he that marries a fortune, covets a Mistress, not loves
her: But if you take Marriage for sign of love, take it from me immediately.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: No, now you have put a scruple in my head; but in short, Sir, to end our dispute, I must marry him, my reputation wou'd suffer in the World else.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, if you do marry him, with your pardon, Madam, your reputation suffers in the World, and you wou'd be thought in necessity for a cloak.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Nay, now you are rude, Sir.—Mr. Sparkish, pray come hither, your Friend here is very troublesom, and very loving.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Hold, hold— Aside to Alithea.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: D'ye hear that?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Why, d'ye think I'll seem to be jealous, like a Country Bumpkin?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, rather be a Cuckold, like a credulous Cit.A citizen. A "credulous cit" would be a unsuspecting or overly gullible citizen.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Madam, you wou'd not have been so little generous as to have told him.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Yes, since you cou'd be so little generous, as to wrong him.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Wrong him, no Man can do't, he's beneath an injury; a Bubble, a Coward, a sensless Idiot, a Wretch so contemptible to all the World but you, that—

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Hold, do not rail at him, for since he is like to be my Husband, I am resolved to like him: Nay, I think I am oblig'd to tell him, you are not his Friend.— Master Sparkish, Master Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: What, what; now dear Rogue, has not she wit?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Not so much as I thought, and hoped she had. Speaks surlily.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Mr. Sparkish, do you bring People to rail at you?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Madam—

sp.speaker: Spar
sp.l: How! no, but if he does rail at me, 'tis but in jest I warrant; what we wits do for one another, and never take any notice of it.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: He spoke so scurrilously of you, I had no patience to hear him; besides he has been making love to me.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: True damn'd tell-tale-Woman. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, to shew his parts—we wits rail and make love often, but to shew our parts; as we have no affections, so we have no malice, we—

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: He said, you were a Wretch, below an injury.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Damn'd, sensless, impudent, virtuous Jade; well since she won't let me have her, she'l do as good, she'l make me hate her.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: A Common Bubble.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: A Coward.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, pshaw.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: A sensless driveling Idiot.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How, did he disparage my parts? Nay, then my honour's concern'd, I can't put up that, Sir; by the World, Brother help me to kill him; [I may draw now, since we have the odds of him:—'tis a good occasion too before my Mistriss]— Aside. Offers to draw.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: What, what.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I must not let'em kill the Gentleman neither, for his kindness to me; I am so far from hating him, that I wish my Gallant had his person and understanding:— [Nay if my honour— Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: I'll be thy death.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Hold, hold, indeed to tell the truth, the Gentleman said after all, that what he spoke, was but out of friendship to you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How! say, I am, I am a Fool, that is no wit, out of friendship to me.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Yes, to try whether I was concern'd enough for you, and made love to me only to be satisfy'd of my virtue, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Kind however— Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, if it were so, my dear Rogue, I ask thee pardon; but why wou'd not you tell me so, faith.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Because I did not think on't, faith.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come, Horner does not come, Harcourt, let's be gone to the new Play.—Come Madam.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I will not go, if you intend to leave me alone in the Box, and run into the pit, as you use to do.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, I'll leave Harcourt with you in the Box, to entertain you, and that's as good; if I sate in the Box, I shou'd be thought no Judge, but of trimmings.—Come away Harcourt, lead her down. Exeunt Sparkish, Harcourt, and Alithea.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, go thy wayes, for the flower of the true Town Fops, such as spend their Estates, before they come to'em, and are Cuckolds before they'r married. But let me go look to my own Free-hold—How— Enter my Lady Fidget, Mistriss Dainty Fidget, and Mistriss Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir, where is your Lady? we are come to wait upon her to the new Play.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: New Play!

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: And my Husband will wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Damn your civility— Madam, by no means, I will not see Sir Jaspar here, till I have waited upon him at home; nor shall my Wife see you, till she has waited upon your Ladyship at your lodgings.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Now we are here, Sir—

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Pray, let us see her.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: We will not stir, till we see her.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: A Pox on you all— Aside. Goes to the door, and returns. she has lock'd the door, and is gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, you have lock'd the door, and she's within.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: They told us below, she was here.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l:
[Will nothing do?]—Well it must out then, to tell you the truth, Ladies, which I was afraid to let you know before, least it might endanger your lives, my Wife has just now the Small Pox come out upon her, do not be frighten'd;
but pray, be gone Ladies, you shall not stay here in danger of your lives; pray get you gone Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, no, we have all had'em.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Alack, alack.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Come, come, we must see how it goes with her, I understand the disease.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, there is no being too hard for Women at their own weapon, lying, therefore I'll quit the Field. Aside. Exit Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Here's an example of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Indeed as the World goes, I wonder there are no more jealous, since Wives are so neglected.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Pshaw, as the World goes, to what end shou'd they be jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Foh, 'tis a nasty World.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: That Men of parts, great acquaintance, and quality shou'd take up with, and spend themselves and fortunes, in keeping little Play-house Creatures, foh.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Nay, that Women of understanding, great acquaintance, and good quality, shou'd fall a keeping too of little Creatures, foh.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Why, 'tis the Men of qualities fault, they never visit Women of honour, and reputation, as they us'd to do; and have not so much as common civility, for Ladies of our rank, but use us with the same indifferency, and ill breeding, as if we were all marry'd to'em.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: She says true, 'tis an errant shame Women of quality shou'd be so slighted; methinks, birth, birth, shou'd go for something; I have known Men admired, courted, and followed for their titles only.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Ay, one wou'd think Men of honour shou'd not love no more, than marry out their own rank.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Fye, fye upon'em, they are come to think cross breeding for themselves best, as well as for their Dogs, and Horses.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: They are Dogs, and Horses for't.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: One wou'd think if not for love, for vanity a little.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Nay, they do satisfy their vanity upon us sometimes; and are kind to us in their report, tell all the World they lye with us.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Damn'd Rascals, that we shou'd be only wrong'd by'em; to a report a Man has had a Person, when he has not had a Person, is the greatest wrong in the whole World, that can be done to a person.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Well, 'tis an errant shame, Noble Persons shou'd be so wrong'd, and neglected.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: But still 'tis an erranter shame for a Noble Person, to neglect her own honour, and defame her own Noble Person, with little inconsiderable Fellows, foh!—

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: I suppose the crime against our honour, is the same with a Man of quality as with another.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: How! no sure the Man of quality is likest one's Husband, and therefore the fault shou'd be the less.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: But then the pleasure shou'd be the less.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Fye, fye, fye, for shame Sister, whither shall we ramble? be continent in your discourse, or I shall hate you.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Besides an intrigue is so much the more notorious for the man's quality.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: 'Tis true, no body takes notice of a private Man, and therefore with him, 'tis more secret, and the crime's the less, when 'tis not known.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: You say true; y faith I think you are in the right on't: 'tis not an injury to a Husband, till it be an injury to our honours; so that a Woman of honour looses no honour with a private Person; and to say truth—

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: So the little Fellow is grown a private Person— with her— Apart to Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: But still my dear, dear Honour. Enter Sir Jaspar, Horner, Dorilant.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, my dear, dear of honour, thou hast still so much honour in thy mouth—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: That she has none elsewhere— Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Oh, what d'ye mean to bring in these upon us?

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Foh, these are bad as Wits,

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Foh!

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Let us leave the Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Stay, stay, faith to tell you the naked truth.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Fye, Sir Jaspar, do not use that word naked.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Well, well, in short I have business at Whitehal, and cannot go to the play with you, therefore wou'd have you go—

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: With those two to a Play?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: No, not with t'other, but with Mr. Horner, there can be no more scandal to go with him, than with Mr. Tatle, or Master Limberham.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: With that nasty Fellow! no—no.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nay, prethee Dear, hear me. Whispers to Lady Fidget

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ladies. Horner, Dorilant drawing near Squeamish, and Daint.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Stand off.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Do not approach us.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: You heard with the wits, you are obscenity all over.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: And I wou'd as soon look upon a Picture of Adam and Eve, without fig leaves, as any of you, if I cou'd help it, therefore keep off, and do not make us sick.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: What a Divel are these?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, these are pretenders to honour, as criticks to wit, only by censuring others; and as every raw peevish, out-of-humour'd, affected, dull, Tea-drinking, Arithmetical Fop sets up for a wit, by railing at men of sence, so these for honour, by railing at the Court, and Ladies of as great honour, as quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Come, Mr. Horner , I must desire you to go with these Ladies to the Play, Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I! Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, ay, come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I must beg your pardon, Sir, and theirs, I will not be seen in Womens Company in publick again for the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ha, ha, strange Aversion!

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: No, he's for Womens company in private.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: He—poor Man—he! hah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l:
'Tis a greater shame amongst lew'd fellows to be
seen in virtuous Womens company, than for the Women to be seen with them.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Indeed, Madam, the time was I only hated virtuous Women, but now I hate the other too; I beg your pardon Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: You are very obliging, Sir, because we wou'd not be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: In sober sadness he shall go.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Nay, if he wo'not, I am ready to wait upon the Ladies; and I think I am the fitter Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: You, Sir, no I thank you for that—Master Horner is a privileg'd Man amongst the virtuous Ladies, 'twill be a great while before you are so; heh, he, he, he's my Wive's Gallant, heh, he; no pray withdraw, Sir, for as I take it, the virtuous Ladies have no business with you.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: And I am sure, he can have none with them: 'tis strange a Man can't come amongst virtuous Women now, but upon the same terms, as Men are admitted into the great Turks Scraglio; but Heavens keep me, from being an hombre Player with'em: but where is Pinchwife — Exit Dorilant.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Come, come, Man; what avoid the sweet society of Woman-kind? that sweet, soft, gentle, tame, noble Creature Woman, made for Man's Companion—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So is that soft, gentle, tame, and more noble creature a Spaniel, and has all their tricks, can fawn, lye down, suffer beating, and fawn the more; barks at your Friends, when they come to see you; makes your bed hard, gives you Fleas, and the mange sometimes: and all the difference is, the Spaniel's the more faithful Animal, and fawns but upon one Master.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Heh, he, he.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: O the rude Beast.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Insolent brute.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Brutel stinking mortify'd rotter French Weather, to date—

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l:
Hold, an't please your Ladyship; for shame Master,
Horner your Mother was a Woman— [Now shall I never reconcile'em] Aside. Hark you, Madam, take my advice in your anger; you know you often want one to make up your droling pack of hombre Players; and you may cheat him easily, for he's an ill Gamester, and consequently loves play: Besides you know, you have but two old civil Gentlemen (with stinking breaths too) to wait upon you abroad, take in the third, into your service; the other are but crazy: and a Lady shou;d have a horse, least sometimes you shou'd be forc'd to stay at home.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: But are you sure he loves play, and has money?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: He loves play as much as you, and has money as much as I.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Then I am contented to make him pay for his scurrillity; money makes up in a measure all other wants in Men.— Those whom we cannot make hold for Gallants, we make fine. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: So, so; now to mollify, to wheedle him,— Aside. Master Horner will you never keep civil Company, methinks 'tis time now, since you are only fit for them: Come, come, Man you must e'en fall to visiting our Wives, eating at our Tables, drinking Tea with our virtuous Relations after dinner, dealing Cards to'em, reading. Plays, and Gazets to'em, picking Fleas out of their shocks for'em, collecting Receipts; New Songs, Women, Pages, and Footmen for'em.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I hope they'l afford me better employment, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Heh, he, he, 'tis fit you know your work before you come into your place; and since you are unprovided of a Lady to flatter, and a good house to eat at, pray frequent mine, and call my Wife Mistriss, and she shall call you Gallant, according to the custom.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Who I?—

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Faith, thou sha't for my sake, come for my sake only.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: For your sake—

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l:
Come, come, here's a Gamester for you, let him
be a little familiar sometimes; nay, what if a little rude; Gamesters may be rude with Ladies, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: yes, losing Gamesters have a privilege with Women.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I alwayes thought the contrary, that the winning Gamester had most privilege with Women, for when you have lost your money to a Man, you'l loose any thing you have, all you have, they say, and he may use you as he pleases.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Heh, he, well, win or loose you shall have your liberty with her.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: As he behaves himself; and for your sake I'll give him admittance and freedom.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: All sorts of freedom, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay, all sorts of freedom thou can'st take, and so go to her, begin thy new employment; wheedle her, jest with her, and be better acquainted one with another.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I think I know her already, therefore may venture with her, my secret for hers— Aside. Horner, and Lady Fidget whisper.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Sister Cuz, I have provided an innocent Play-fellow for you there.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Who he!

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: There's a play-fellow indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Yes sure, what he is good enough to play at Cards, Blind-mans buff, or the fool with sometimes.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Foh, we'l have no such Play-fellows.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: No, Sir, you shan't choose Play-fellows for us, we thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nay, pray hear me. Whispering to them.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: But, poor Gentleman, cou'd you be so generous? so truly a Man of honour, as for the sakes of us Women of honour, to cause your self to be reported no Man? No Man! and to suffer your self the greatest shame that cou'd fall upon a Man, that none might fall upon us Women by your conversation; but indeed, Sir, as perfectly, the same Man as before your going into France , Sir; as perfectly, perfectly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: As perfectly, perfectly, Madam; nay, I scorn you shou'd take my word; I desire to be try'd only, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Well, that's spoken again like a Man of honour, all Men of honour desire to come to the test: But indeed, generally you Men report such things of your selves, one does not know how, or whom to believe; and it is come to that pass, we dare not take your words, no more than your Taylors, without some staid Servant of yours be bound with you; but I have so strong a faith in your honour, dear, dear, noble Sir, that I'd forfeit mine for yours at any time, dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, Madam, you shou'd not need to forfeit it for me, I have given you security already to save you harmless my late reputation being so well known in the World, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But if upon any future falling out, or upon a suspition of my taking the trust out of your hands, to employ some other, you your self shou'd betray your trust, dear Sir; I mean, if you'l give me leave to speak obscenely, you might tell, dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I I did, no body wou'd believe me; the reputation of impotency is as hardly recover'd again in the World, as that of cowardise, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Nay then, as one may say, you may do your worst, dear, dear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Come, is your Ladyship reconciled to him yet? have you agreed on matters? for I must be gone to White- hal.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Why, indeed, Sir Jaspar, Master Horner is a thousand, thousand times a better Man, than I thought him: Cosen Squeamish, Sister Dainty, I can name him now, truly not long ago you know, I thought his very name obscenity, and I wou'd as soon have lain with him, as have nam'd him.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Very likely, poor Madam.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: I believe it.

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l:
Well, well—that your Ladyship is as virtuous as any she,—I know, and him all the Town knows—heh, he,
he; therefore now you like him, get you gone to your business together; go, go, to your business, I say, pleasure, whilst I go to my pleasure, business.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Come than dear Gallant.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Come away, my dearest Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: So, so, why 'tis as I'd have it. Exit Sr. Jaspar

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And as I'd have it.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Who for his business, from his Wife will run;
Takes the best care, to have her bus'ness done.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Sister, what ailes you, you are grown melancholy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Wou'd it not make any one melancholy, to see you go every day fluttering about abroad, whil'st I must stay at home like a poor lonely, sullen Bird in a cage?

sp.speaker: Alit.
sp.l: Ay, Sister, but you came young; and just from the nest to your cage, so that I thought you lik'd it; and cou'd be as chearful in't, as others that took their flight themselves earlym and are hopping abroad in the open Air.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, I confess I was quiet enough, till my Husband told me, what pure lives, the London Ladies live abroad, with their dancing, meetings, and junketings, and drest every day in their best gowns; and I warrant you, play at nine Pins every day of the week, so they do. Enter Mr. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, what's here to do? you are putting the Town pleasures in her head, and setting her a longing.

sp.speaker: Alit.
sp.l: Yes, after Nine-pins; you suffer none to give her those longings, you mean, but your self.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I tell her of the vanities of the Town like a Confessor.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: A Confessor! just such a Confessor, as he that by forbidding a silly Oastler to grease the Horses teeth, taught him to do't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come Mistriss Flippant , good Precepts are lost, when bad Examples are still before us; the liberty you take abroad makes her hanker after it; and out of humour at home, poor Wretch! she desired not to come to London , I wou'd bring her.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: She has been this week in Town, and never desired, till this afternoon, to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Was she not at a Play yesterday?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, but she ne'er ask'd me; I was my self the cause of her going.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Then if she ask you again, you are the cause of her asking, and not my example.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, tomorrow night I shall be rid of you; and the next day before 'tis light, she and I'll be rid of the Town, and my dreadful apprehensions: Come, be not melancholly, for thou sha't go into the Country after to morrow, Dearest.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Great comfort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pish, what d'ye tell me of the Country for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How's this! what, pish at the Country?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let me alone, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O, if that be all—what ailes my dearest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Truly I don't know; but I have not been well, since you told me there was a Gallant at the Play in love with me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ha—

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: That's by my example too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, if you are not well, but are so concern'd, because a lew'd Fellow chanc'd to lye, and say he lik'd you, you'l make me sick too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Of what sickness?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O, of that which is worse than the Plague Jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pish, you jear, I'm sure there's no such disease in our Receipt-book at home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, thou never met'st with it, poor Innocent— well, if thou Cuckold me, 'twill be my own fault— for Cuckolds and Bastards, are generally makers of their own fortune. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, but pray Bud, let's go to a Play to night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis just done, she comes from it; but why are you so eager to see a Play?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Faith Dear, not that I care one pin for their talk there; but I like to look upon the Player-men, and wou'd

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
