sp.l: Pish, what d'ye tell me of the Country for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How's this! what, pish at the Country?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let me alone, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O, if that be all—what ailes my dearest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Truly I don't know; but I have not been well, since you told me there was a Gallant at the Play in love with me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ha—

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: That's by my example too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, if you are not well, but are so concern'd, because a lew'd Fellow chanc'd to lye, and say he lik'd you, you'l make me sick too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Of what sickness?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O, of that which is worse than the Plague Jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pish, you jear, I'm sure there's no such disease in our Receipt-book at home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, thou never met'st with it, poor Innocent— well, if thou Cuckold me, 'twill be my own fault— for Cuckolds and Bastards, are generally makers of their own fortune. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, but pray Bud, let's go to a Play to night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis just done, she comes from it; but why are you so eager to see a Play?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Faith Dear, not that I care one pin for their talk there; but I like to look upon the Player-men, and wou'd see, if I cou'd, the Gallant you say loves me; that's all dear Bud.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Is that all dear Bud?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: This proceeds from my example.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: But if the Play be done, let's go abroad however, dear Bud.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come have a little patience, and thou shalt go into the Country on Friday.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Therefore I wou'd see first some sights, to tell my Neighbours of. Nay, I will go abroad, that's once.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I'm the cause of this desire too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But now I think on't, who was the cause of Hor- ners coming to my Lodging to day? that was you.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: No, you, because you wou'd not let him see your handsome Wife out of your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why, O Lord! did the Gentleman come hither to see me indeed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, no;—You are not cause of that damn'd question too, Mistriss Alithea? —[Well she's in the right of it; he is in love with my Wife—and comes after her— 'tis so—but I'll nip his love in the bud; least he should follow us into the Country, and break his Chariot-wheel near our house, on purpose for an excuse to come to't; but I think I know the Town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, pray Bud, let's go abroad before 'tis late; for I will go, that's flat and plain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So! the obstinacy already of a Town-wife, and I must, whilst she's here, humour her like one. Aside. Sister, how shall we do, that she may not be seen, or known?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Let her put on her Mask.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pshaw, a Mask makes People but the more inquisitive, and is as ridiculous a disguise, as a stage-beard; her shape, stature, habit will be known: and if we shou'd meet with Horner , he wou'd be sure to take acquaintance with us, must wish her joy, kiss her, talk to her, leer upon her, and the Devil and all; no I'll not use her to a Mask, 'tis dangerous; for Masks have made more Cuckolds, than the best faces that ever were known.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: How will you do then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, shall we go? the Exchange will be shut, and I have a mind to see that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So—I have it—I'll dress her up in the Suit, we are to carry down to her Brother, little Sir James ; nay, I understand the Town tricks: Come let's go dress her; a Mask! no—a Woman mask'd, like a cover'd Dish, gives a Man curiosity, and appetite, when, it may be, uncover'd, 'twou'd turn his stomack; no, no.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Indeed your comparison is something a greasie one: but I had a gentle Gallant, us'd to say, a Beauty mask'd, lik'd the Sun in Eclipse, gathers together more gazers, than if it shin'd out.

div.stage: The Scene changes to the new Exchange: Enter Horner, Harcourt, Dorilant.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Engag'd to Women, and not Sup with us?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, a Pox on'em all.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: You were much a more reasonable Man in the morning, and had as noble resolution against'em, as a Widdower of a weeks liberty.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Did I ever think, to see you keep company with Women in vain.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: In vain! no —'tis, since I can't love'em, to be reveng'd on'em.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Now your Sting is gone, you look'd in the Box amongst all those Women, like a drone in the hive, all upon you; shov'd and ill-us'd by'em all, and thrust from one side to t'other.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Yet he must be buzzing amongst'em still, like other old beetle-headed, lycorish drones; avoid'em, and hate'm as they hate you.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Because I do hate'em, and wou'd hate'em yet more, I'll frequent'em; you may see by Marriage, nothing makes a Man hate a Woman more, than her constant conversation: In short, I converse with'em, as you do with rich Fools, to laugh at'em, and use'em ill.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: But I wou'd no more Sup with Women, unless I cou'd lye with'em, than Sup with a rich Coxcomb, unless I cou'd cheat him.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Yes, I have known thee Sup with a Fool, for his drinking, if he cou'd set out your hand that way only, you were satisfy'd; and if he were a Wine-swallowing mouth 'twas enough.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Yes, a Man drink's often with a Fool, as he tosses with a Marker, only to keep his hand in Ure; but do the Ladies drink?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Yes, Sir, and I shall have the pleasure at least of laying'em flat with a Bottle; and bring as much scandal that way upon'em, as formerly t'other.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Perhaps you may prove as weak a Brother amongst'em that way, as t'other.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Foh, drinking with Women, is as unnatural, as scolding with'em; but 'tis a pleasure of decay'd Fornicators, and the basest way of quenching Love.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Nay, 'tis drowning Love, instead of quenching it; but leave us for civil Women too!

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Ay, when he can't be the better for'em; we hardly pardon a Man, that leaves his Friend for a Wench, and that's a pretty lawful call.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Faith, I wou'd not leave you for'em, if they wou'd not drink.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Who wou'd disappoint his Company at Lewis 's, for a Gossiping?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l:
Foh, Wine and Women good apart, together as nauseous as Sack and Sugar: But hark you, Sir, before you go, a little of your advice, an old maim'd General, when unfit for actions is fittest for Counsel; I have other designs upon Women, than eating and drinking with them: I am in
love with Sparkish 's Mistriss, whom he is to marry to morrow, now how shall I get her? Enter Sparkish, looking about.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, here comes one will help you to her.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: He! he, I tell you, is my Rival, and will hinder my love.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, a foolish Rival, and a jealous Husband assist their Rivals designs; for they are sure to make their Women hate them, which is the first step to their love, for another Man.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: But I cannot come near his Mistriss, but in his company.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Still the better for you, for Fools are most easily cheated, when they themselves are accessaries; and he is to be bubled of his Mistriss, as of his Money, the common Mistriss, by keeping him company.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Who is that, that is to be bubled? Faith let me snack, I han't met with a buble since Christmas: gad; I think bubles are like their Brother Woodcocks, go out with the cold weather.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: A Pox, he did not hear all I hope. Apart to Horner.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come, you bubling Rogues you, where do we sup —Oh, Harcourt , my Mistriss tells me, you have been making fierce love to her all the Play long, hah, ha — but I —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I make love to her?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, I forgive thee; for I think I know thee, and I know her, but I am sure I know my self.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Did she tell you so? I see all Women are like these of the Exchange , who to enhance the price of their commodities, report to their fond Customers offers which were never made'em.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, Women are as apt to tell before the intrigue, as Men after it, and so shew themselves the vainer Sex; but hast thou a Mistriss, Sparkish ? 'tis as hard for me to believe it, as that thou ever hadst a buble, as tou brag'd just now.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l:
O your Servant, Sir; are you at your raillery, Sir? but we were some of us beforehand with you to day at the
Play: the Wits were something bold with you, Sir; did you not hear us laugh?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Yes, But I thought you had gone to Plays, to laugh at the Poets wit, not at your own.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir, no thank you; gad I go to a Play as to a Country-treat, I carry my own wine to one, and my own wit to t'other, or else I'm sure I shou'd not be merry at either; and the reason why we are so often lowder, than the players, is, because we think we speak more wit, and so become the Poets Rivals in his audience: for to tell you the truth, we hate the silly Rogues; nay, so much that we find fault even with their Bawdy upon the Stage, whilst we talk nothing else in the Pit as lowd.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But, why should'st thou hate the silly Poets, thou hast too much wit to be one, and they like Whores are only hated by each other; and thou dost scorn writing, I'am sure.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Yes, I'd have you to know, I scorn writing; but Women, Women, that make Men do all foolish things, make'em write Songs too; every body does it: 'tis ev'n as common with Lovers, as playing with fans; and you can no more help Rhyming to your Phyllis , than drinking to your Phyllis.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Nay, Poetry in love is no more to be avoided, than jealousy.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: But the Poets damn'd your Songs, did they?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Damn the Poets, they turn'd'em into Burlesque, as they call it; that Burlesque is a Hocus-Pocus -trick, they have got, which by the virtue of Hictius doctius, topsey turvey , they make a wise and witty Man in the World, a Fool upon the Stage you know not how; and 'tis therefore I hate'em too, for I know not but it may be my own case; for they'l put a Man into a Play for looking a Squint: Their Predecessors were contented to make Serving-men only their Stage-Fools, but these Rogues must have Gentlemen, with a Pox to'em, nay Knights: and indeed you shall hardly see a Fool upon the Stage, but he's a Knight; and to tell you the truth, they have kept me these six years from being a Knight in earnest, for fear of being knighted in a Play, and dubb'd a Fool.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Blame'em not, they must follow their Copy, the Age.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: But why should'st thou be afraid of being in a Play, who expose your self every day in the Play-houses, and as publick Places.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: 'Tis but being on the Stage, instead of standing on a Bench in the Pit.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Don't you give money to Painters to draw you like? and are you afraid of your Pictures, at length in a Play-house, where all your Mistresses may see you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: A Pox, Painters don't draw the Small Pox, or Pimples in ones face; come damn all your silly Authors whatever, all Books and Booksellers, by the World, and all Readers, courteous or uncourteous.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: But, who comes here, Sparkish? Enter Mr. Pinchwife, and his Wife in Mans Cloaths, Alithea, Lucy her Maid.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Oh hide me, there's my Mistriss too. Sparkish hides himself behind Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: She sees you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: But I will not see her, 'tis time to go to Whitehal , and I must not fail the drawing Room.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Pray, first carry me, and reconcile me to her.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Another time, faith the King will have sup't.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Not with the worse stomach for thy absence; thou art one of those Fools, that think their attendance at the King's Meals, as necessary as his Physicians, when you are more troublesom to him, than his Doctors, or his Dogs.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, I know my interest, Sir, prethee hide me.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Your Servant, Pinchwife , —what he knows us not —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come along. To his Wife aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray, have you any Ballads, give me six-penny worth?

sp.speaker: Claspa.
sp.l: We have no Ballads.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Then give me Covent-garden -Drollery, and a Play or two —Oh here's Tarugos Wiles, and the Slighted Maiden, I'll have them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, Playes are not for your reading; come along, will you discover your self? Apart to her.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Who is that pretty Youth with him, Sparkish?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: I believe his Wife's Brother, because he's something like her, but I never saw her but once.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Extreamly handsom, I have seen a face like it too; let us follow'em. Exeunt Pinchwife, Mistriss Pinchwife. Alithea, Lucy, Horner, Dorilant following them.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Come, Sparkish , your Mistriss saw you, and will be angry you go not to her; besides I wou'd fain be reconcil'd to her, which none but you can do, dear Friend.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Well that's a better reason, dear Friend; I wou'd not go near her now, for her's, or my own sake, but I can deny you nothing; for though I have known thee a great while, never go, if I do not love thee, as well as a new Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I am oblig'd to you indeed, dear Friend, I wou'd be well with her only, to be well with thee still; for these tyes to Wives usually dissolve all tyes to Friends: I wou'd be contented, she shou'd enjoy you a nights, but I wou'd have you to my self a dayes, as I have had, dear Friend.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: And thou shalt enjoy me a dayes, dear, dear Friend, never stir; and I'll be divorced from her, sooner than from thee; come along —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: So we are hard put to't, when we make our Rival our Procurer; but neither she, nor her Brother, wou'd let me come near her now: when all's done, a Rival is the best cloak to steal to a Mistress under, without suspicion; and when we have once got to her as we desire, we throw him off like other Cloaks. Aside. Exit Sparkish, and Harcourt following him. Re-enter Mr. Pinchwife, Mistress Pinchwife in Man's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Sister, if you will not go, we must leave you — To Alithea. The Fool her Gallant, and she, will muster up all the young
santerers of this place, and they will leave their dear Seamstresses to follow us; what a swarm of Cuckolds, and Cuckold-makers are here? Aside. Come let's be gone Mistriss Margery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Don't you believe that, I han't half my belly full of sights yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Then walk this way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Lord, what a power of brave signs are here! stay —the Bull's-head, the Rams-head, and the Stags-head, Dear —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, if every Husbands proper sign here were visible, they wou'd be all alike.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What d'ye mean by that, Bud?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis no matter —no matter, Bud.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray tell me; nay, I will know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: They wou'd be all Bulls, Stags, and Rams heads. Exeunt Mr. Pinchwife, Mrs. Pinchwife. Re-enter Sparkish, Harcourt, Alithea, Lucy, at t'other door.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come dear Madam, for my sake you shall be reconciled to him.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: For your sake I hate him.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: That's something too cruel, Madam, to hate me for his sake.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay indeed, Madam, too, too cruel to me, to hate my Friend for my sake.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I hate him because he is your Enemy; and you ought to hate him too, for making love to me, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: That's a good one, I hate a Man for loving you; if he did love you, 'tis but what he can't help, and 'tis your fault not his, if he admires you: I hate a Man for being of my opinion, I'll ne'er do't, by the World.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Is it for your honour or mine, to suffer a Man to make love to me, who am to marry you yo morrow?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Is it for your honour or mine, to have me jealous? That he makes love to you, is a sign you are handsome; and that I am not jealous, is a sign you are virtuous, that I think is for your honour.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: But 'tis your honour too, I am concerned for.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: But why, dearest Madam, will you be more concern'd for his honour, than he is himself; let his honour alone for my sake, and his, he, he, has no honour —

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: But what, my dear Friend can guard himself.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: O ho —that's right again.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Your care of his honour argues his neglect of it, which is no honour to my dear Friend here; therefore once more, let his honour go which way it will, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay, ay, were it for my honour to marry a Woman, whose virtue I suspected, and cou'd not trust her in a Friends hands?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Are you not afraid to loose me?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: He afraid to loose you, Madam! No, no —you may see how the most estimable, and most glorious Creature in the World, is valued by him; will you not see it?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Right, honest Franck , I have that noble value for her, that I cannot be jealous of her.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: You mistake him, he means you care not for me, nor who has me.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Lord, Madam, I see you are jealous; will you wrest a poor Mans meaning from his words?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: You astonish me, Sir, with your want of jealousie.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: And you make me guiddy, Madam, with your jealousie, and fears, and virtue, and honour; gad, I see virtue makes a Woman as troublesome, as a little reading, or learning.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Monstrous!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: [Well to see what easie Husbands these Women of quality can meet with, a poor Chamber-maid can never have such Lady-like luck; besides he's thrown away upon her, she'l make no use of her fortune, her blessing, none to a Gentleman, for a pure Cuckold, for it requires good breeding to be a Cuckold. Behind.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I tell you then plainly, her pursues me to marry me.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Come, Madam, you see you strive in vain to make him jealous of me; my dear friend is the kindest Creature in the World to me.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: But his kindness only is not enough for me, without your favour; your good opinion, dear Madam, 'tis that must perfect my happiness: good Gentleman he believes all I say, wou'd you wou'd do so, jealous of me! I wou'd not wrong him nor you for the World.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Look you there; hear him, hear him, and do not walk away so. Alithea walks carelessly to and fro.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I love you, Madam, so —

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How's that! Nay —now you begin to go too far indeed.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: So much I confess, I say I love you, that I wou'd not have you miserable, and cast your self away upon so unworhty, and inconsiderable a thing, as what you see here. Clapping his hand on his breast, points at Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No faith, I believe thou woud'st not, now his meaning is plain: but I knew before thou woud'st not wrong me nor her.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, no, Heavens forbid, the glory of her Sex shou'd fall so low as into the embraces of such a contemptible Wretch, the last of Mankind —my dear Friend here — I injure him. Embracing Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No, no, dear Friend, I knew it Madam, you see he will rather wrong himself that me, in giving himself such names.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Do not you understand him yet?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Yes, how modestly he speaks of himself, poor Fellow.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Methinks he speaks impudently of your self, since— before your self too, insomuch that I can no longer suffer his scurrilous abusiveness to you, no more than his love to me. Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, nay, Madam, pray stay, his love to you: Lord, Madam, has he not spoke yet plain enough?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Yes indeed, I shou'd think so.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Well then, by the World, a Man can't speak civilly to a Woman now, but presently she says, he makes love to her: Nay, Madam, you shall stay, with your pardon, since you have not yet understood him, till he has made an eclaircissment of his love to you, that is what kind of love it is; answer to thy Catechisme: Friend, do you love my Mistriss here?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Yes, I wish she wou'd not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: But how do you love her?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: With all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I thank him, methinks he speaks plain enough now.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: You are out still. to Alithea. But with what kind of love, Harcourt?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: With the best, and truest love in the World.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Look you there then, that is with no matrimonial love, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: How's that, do you say matrimonial love is not best?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Gad, I went too far e're I was aware: But speak for thy self Harcourt , you said you wou'd not wrong me, not her.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: No, no, Madam, e'n take him for Heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Look you there, Madam.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Who shou'd in all justice be yours, he that loves you most. Claps his hand on his breast.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Look you there, Mr. Sparkish , who's that?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Who shou'd it be? go on Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Who loves you more than Women, Titles, or fortune Fools. Points at Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Look you there, he means me stil, for he points at me.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Who can only match your Faith, and constancy in love.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Who knows, if it be possible, how to value so much beauty and virtue.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Whose love can no more be equall'd in the world, than that Heavenly form of yours.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Who cou'd no more suffer a Rival, than your absence, and yet cou'd no more suspect your virtue, than his own constancy in his love to you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Who in fine loves you better than his eyes, that first made him love you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay —nay, Madam, faith you shan't go, till —

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Have a care, left you make me stay too long —

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: But till he has saluted you; that I may be assur'd you are friends, after his honest advice and declaration: Come pray, Madam, be friends with him. Enter Master Pinchwife, Mistriss Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: You must pardon me, Sir, that I am not yet so obedient to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What, invite your Wife to kiss Men? Monstrous, are you not asham'd? I will never forgive you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Are you not asham'd, that I shou'd have more confidence in the chastity of your Family, than you have; you must not teach me, I am a man of honour, Sir, though I am frank and free; I am frank, Sir —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Very frank, Sir, to share your Wife with your friends.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: He is an humble menial Friend, such as reconciles the differences of the Marriage bed; you know Man and Wife do not alwayes agree, I design him for that use, therefore wou'd have him well with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: A menial Friend —you will get a great many menial Friends, by shewing your Wife as you do.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: What then, it may be I have a pleasure in't, as I have to shew fine Clothes, at a Play-house the first day, and count money before poor Rogues.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: He that shews his wife, or money will be in danger of having them borrowed sometimes.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: I love to be envy'd, and wou'd not marry a Wife, that I alone cou'd love; loving alone is a dull, as eating alone; is it not a frank age, and I am a frank Person? and to tell you the truth, it may be I love to have Rivals in a Wife, they make her seem to a Man still, but as a kept Mistriss; and so good night, for I must to Whitehal. Madam, I hope you are now reconcil'd to my Friend; and so I wish you a good night, Madam, and sleep if you can, for to morrow you know I must visit you early with a Canonical Gentleman. Good night dear Harcourt. Exit Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Madam, I hope you will not refuse my visit to morrow, if it shou'd be earlyer, with a Canonical Gentleman, than Mr. Sparkish's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: This Gentle-woman is yet under my care, therefore you must yet forbear your freedom with her, Sir. Coming between Alithea and Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Must, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, Sir, she is my Sister.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: 'Tis well she is, Sir —for I must be her Servant, Sir. Madam —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come away Sister, we had been gone, if it had not been for you, and so avoided these lewd Rakehells, who seem to haunt us. Enter Horner, Dorilant to them.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: How now Pinchwife?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What, I see a little time in the Country makes a Man turn wild and unsociable, and only fit to converse with his Horses, Dogs, and his Herds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I have business, Sir, and must mind it; your business is pleasure, therefore you and I must go different wayes.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well, you may go on, but this pretty young Gentleman —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: The Lady —

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: And the Maid —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Shall stay with us, for I suppose their business is the same with ours, pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Sdeath he knows her, she carries it so sillily, yet if he does not, I shou'd be more silly to discover it first. Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Pray, let us go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, come —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Had you not rather stay with us? to Mrs. Pinchwife. Prethee Pinchwife , who is this pretty young Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: One to whom I'm a guardian. [I wish I cou'd keep her out of your hands — Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Who is he? I never saw any thing so pretty in all my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pshaw, do not look upon him so much, he's a poor bashful youth, you'l put him out of countenance. Come away Brother. Offers to take her away.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: O your Brother!

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, my Wifes Brother; come, come, she'l stay supper for us.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I thought so, for he is very like her I saw you at the Play with, whom I told you, I was in love with.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Jeminy! is this he that was in love with me, I am glad on't I vow, for he's a curious fine Gentleman, and I love him already too. Aside. Is this he Bud? to Mr. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come away, come away. To his Wife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, what hast are you in? why wont you let me talk with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Because you'l debauch him, he's yet young and innocent, and I wou'd not have him debauch'd for any thing in the World. How she gazes on him! the Divel — Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Harcourt, Dorilant , look you here, this is the likeness of that Dowdey he told us of, his Wife, did you ever see a lovelyer Creature? the Rogue has reason to be jealous of his Wife, since she is like him, for she wou'd make all that see her, in love with her.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: And as I remember now, she is as like him here as can be.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: She is indeed very pretty, if she be like him.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Very pretty, a very pretty commendation —she is a glorious Creature, beautiful beyond all things I ever beheld.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So, so

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: More beautiful than a Poets first Mistriss of Imagination.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Or another Mans last Mistriss of flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, now you jeer, Sir; pray don't jeer me —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, come. By Heavens she'l discover herself. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I speak of your Sister, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, but saying she was handsom, if like him, made him blush. [I am upon a wrack — Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Methinks he is so handsom, he shou'd not be a Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O there 'tis out, he has discovered her, I am not able to suffer any longer. [Come, come away, I say — To his Wife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, by your leave, Sir, he shall not go yet — Harcourt, Dorilant , let us torment this jealous Rogue a little. To them.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I'll shew you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, pray let him go, I cannot stay fooling any longer; I tell you his Sister stays supper for us.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Do's she, come then we'l all go sup with her and thee.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, now I think on't, having staid so long for us, I warrant she's gone to bed — [I wish she and I were well out of their hands — Aside. Come, I must rise early to morrow, come.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well then, if she be gone to bed, I wish her and you a good night. But pray, young Gentleman, present my humble service to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Thank you heartily, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l:
S'death, she will discover her self yet in spight of me. Aside.
He is something more civil to you, for your kindness to his Sister, than I am, it seems.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Tell her, dear sweet little Gentleman, for all your Brother there, that you have reviv'd the love, I had for her at first sight in the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: But did you love her indeed, and indeed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So, so. Aside. Away, I say.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay stay; yes indeed, and indeed, pray do you tell her so, and give her this kiss from me. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Heavens! what do I suffer; now 'tis too plain he knows her, and yet — Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And this, and this — Kisses her again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What do you kiss me for, I am no Woman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —there 'tis out. Aside. Come, I cannot, nor will stay any longer.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, they shall send your Lady a kiss too; here Har- court, Dorilant , will you not? They kiss her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How, do I suffer this? was I not accusing another just now, for this rascally patience, in permitting his Wife to be kiss'd before his face? ten thousand ulcers gnaw away their lips. Aside. Come, come.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Good night dear Gentleman; Madam goodnight; farewel Pinchwife. Apart to Harcourt and Dorilant. Did not I tell you, I wou'd raise his jealous gall. Exeunt Horner, Harcourt, and Dorilant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So they are gone at last; stay, let me see first if the Coach be at this door. Exit.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What not gone yet? will you be sure to do as I defired you, sweet Sir? Horner, Harcourt, Dorilant return.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Sweet Sir, but what will you give me then?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Any thing, come away into Exit Horner, haling away Mrs. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Hold, hold, —what d'ye do?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Stay, stay, hold —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Hold Madam, hold, let him present him, he'l come presently; nay, I will never let you go, till you answer my question. Alithea, Lucy strugling with Harcourt, and Dorilant.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: For God's sake, Sir, I must follow'em.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: No, I have something to present you with too, you shan't follow them. Pinchwife returns.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Where? —how?—what's become of? gone— whither?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: He's only gone with the Gentleman, who will give him something, an't please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Something —give him something, with a Pox— where are they?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: In the next walk only, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Only, only; where, where? Exit Pinchwife, and returns presently, then goes out again.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: What's the matter with him? why so much concern'd? but dearest Madam —

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Pray, let me go, Sir, I have said, and suffer'd enough already.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Then you will not look upon, nor pitty my sufferings.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: To look upon'em, when I cannot help'em, were cruelty, not pitty, therefore I will never see you more.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Let me then, Madam, have my priviledge of a banished Lover, complaining or railing, and giving you but a farewell reason; why, if you cannot condescend to marry me, you shou'd not take that wretch my Rival.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: He only, not you, since my honour is engag'd so far to him, can give me a reason, why shou'd not marry him; but if he be true, and what I think him to me, I must be so to him; your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Have Women only constancy when 'tis a vice, and like fortune only true to fools?

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l:
Thou sha't not stir thou robust Creature, you see I can deal with you, therefore you shou'd stay the rather,
and be kind. To Lucy, who struggles to get from him. Enter Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Gone, gone, not to be found; quite gone, ten thousand plagues go with'em; which way went they?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: But into t'other walk, Brother.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Their business will be done presently sure, an't please your Worship, it can't be long in doing I'm sure on't.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Are they not there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, you know where they are, you infamous Wretch, Eternal shame of your Family, which you do not dishonour enough your self, you think, but you must help her to do it too, thou legion of Bawds.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Good Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Damn'd, damn'd Sister.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Look you here, she's coming. Enter Mistriss Pinchwife in Mans cloaths, running with her hat under her arm, full of Oranges and dried fruit, Horner following.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O dear Bud, look you here what I have got, see.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: And what I have got here too, Aside rubbing his forehead.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: The fine Gentleman has given me better things yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ha's he so? Aside. Out of breath and colour'd—I must hold yet.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I have only given your little Brother and Orange, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Thank you, Sir. To Horner. You have only squeez'd my Orange, I suppose, and given it me again; yet I must have a City-patience. Aside. Come, come away — To his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Stay, till I have put up my fine things, Bud. Enter Sir Jaspar Fidget.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: O Master Horner, come, come, the Ladies stay for you; your Mistriss, my Wife, wonders you make not more hast to her.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I have staid this half hour for you here, and 'tis your fault I am not now with your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: But pray, don't let her know so much, the truth on't is, I was advancing a certain Project to his Majesty, about —I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, let's go, and hear it at your house: Good night swett little Gentleman; one kiss more, you'l remember me now I hope. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: What, Sir Jaspar , will you separate Friends? he promis'd to sup with us; and if yo take him to your house, you'l be in danger of our company too.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Alas Gentlemen my house is not fit g are none but civil Women there, which are not for your turn; he you know can bear with the society of civil Women, now, ha, ha, ha; besides he's one of my Family; —he's— heh, heh, heh.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Faith my Eunuch, since you'l have it, heh, he, he. Exit Sir Jaspar Fidget, and Horner.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: I rather wish thou wert his, or my Cuckold: Har- court , what a good Cuckold is lost there, for want of a Man to make him one; thee and I cannot have Horners privilege, who can make use of it.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Ay, to poor Horner 'tis like coming to an estate at threescore, when a Man can't be the better for't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Presently Bud.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Come let us go too: Madam, your Servant. To Alithea Good night Strapper. — To Lucy.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Madam, though you will not let me have a good day, or night, I wish you one; but dare not name the other half of my wish.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Good night, Sir, for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I don't know where to put this here, dear Bud, you shall eat it; nay, you shall have part of the fine Gentlemans good things, or treat as you call it, when we come home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Indeed I deserve it, since I furnish'd the best part of it. Strikes away, the Orange.
The Gallant treates, presents, and gives the Ball;
But 'tis the absent Cuckold, pays for all

div.stage: In Pinchwife's house in the morning.
Lucy, Alithea dress'd in new Cloths.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: WEll —Madam, now have I dress'd you, and set you out with so many ornaments, and spent upon you ounces of essence, and pulvilio; and all this for no other purpose, but as People adorn, and perfume a Corps, for a stinking second-hand-grave, such or as bad I think Master Sparkish's bed.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, I will ask you the reason, why you wou'd banish poor Master Harcourt for ever from your sight? how cou'd you be so hard-hearted?

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: 'Twas because I was not hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: No, no; 'twas stark love and kindness, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: It was so; I wou'd see him no more, because I love him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Hey day, a very pretty reason.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: You do not understand me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I wish you may your self.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I was engag'd to marry, you see, another man, whom my justice will not suffer me to deceive, or injure.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Can there be a greater cheat, or wrong done to a Man, than to give him your person, without your heart, I shou'd make a conscience of it.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I'll retrieve it for him after I am married a while.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: The Woman that marries to love better, will be as much mistaken, as the Wencher that marries to live better. No, Madam, marrying to encrease love, is like gaming to become rich; alas you only loose, what little stock you had before.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I find by your Rhetorick you have been brib'd to betray me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Only by his merit, that has brib'd your heart you see against your word, and rigid honour; but what a Divel is this honour? 'tis sure a disease in the head, like the Megrim, of Falling-sickness, that alwayes hurries People away to do themselves mischief; Men loose their lives by it: Women what's dearer to'em, their love, the life of life.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Come, pray talk you no more of honour, nor Master Harcourt , I wish I may never stick pin more, if he be not an errant Natural, to t'other fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I own he wants the wit of Harcourt , which I will dispense withal, for another want he has, which is want of jealousie, which men of wit seldom want.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Lord, Madam, what shou'd you do with a fool to your Husband, you intend to be honest don't you? then that husbandly virtue, credulity, is thrown away upon you.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: He only that could suspect my virtue, shou'd have cause to do it; 'tis Sparkish 's confidence in my truth, that obliges me to be so faithful to him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: You are not sure his opinion may last.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I am satisfied, 'tis impossible for him to be jealous, after the proofs I have had of him: Jealousie in a Husband, Heaven defend me from it, it begets a thousand plagues to a poor Woman, the loss of her honour, her quiet, and her —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And her pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: What d'ye mean, Impertinent?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Liberty is a great pleasure, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I say loss of honour, her quiet, nay, her life sometimes; and what's as bad almost, the loss of this Town, that is, she is sent into the Country, which is the last ill usage of a Husband to a Wife, I think.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: O do's the wind lye there? Aside. Then of necessity, Madam, you think a man must carry his Wife into the Country, if he be wise; the Country is as terrible I find to our young English Ladies, as a Monastery to those abroad: and on my Virginity, I think they wou'd rather marry a London -Goaler, than a high Sheriff of a County, since neither can stir from his employment: formerly Women of wit married Fools, for a great Estate, a fine seat, or the like; but now 'tis for a pretty seat only in Lincoln's Inn-fields , St. James's-fields , or the Pall-mall. Enter to them Sparkish, and Harcourt dress'd like a Parson.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Madam, your humble Servant, a happy day to you, and to us all.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Amen. —

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: My Chaplain faith —O Madam, poor Harcourt remembers his humble service to you; and in obedience to your last commands, refrains coming into your sight.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Is not that he?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No, fye no; but to shew that he ne're intended to hinder our Match has sent his Brother here to joyn our hands: when I get me a Wife, I must get her a Chaplain, according to the Custom; this is his Brother, and my Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: His Brother?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And your Chaplain, to preach in your Pulpit then— Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: His Brother!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And your Chaplain, to preach in your Pulpit then— Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: His Brother!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And your Chaplain, to preach in your Pulpit then—

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay, I knew you wou'd not believe it; I told you, Sir, she wou'd take you for your Brother Frank.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Believe it!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: His Brother! hah, ha, he, he has a trick left still it seems —

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come my dearest, pray let us go to Church before the Canonical hour is past.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: For shame you are abus'd still.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: By the World 'tis strange now you are so incredulous.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: 'Tis strange you are so credulous.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Dearest of my life, hear me, I tell you this is Ned Harcourt of Cambridge , by the world, you see he has a sneaking Colledg look; 'tis true he's something like his Brother Frank , and they differ from each other no more than in their age, for they were Twins.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Hah, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir, I cannot be so deceiv'd, though you are; but come let's hear, how do you know what you affirm so confidently?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
Alithea
sp.l: yes, Frank goes, and puts on a black-coat, then tell's you, he is Ned , that's all you have for't.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, pshaw, I tell you by the same token, the Midwife put her Garter about Frank 's neck, to know'em asunder, they were so like.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Frank tell's you this too.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay, and Ned there too; nay, they are both in a Story.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: So, so, very foolish.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Lord, if you won't believe one, you had best trye him by your Chamber-maid there; for Chamber-maids must needs know Chaplains from other Men, they are so us'd to'em.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Let's see; nay, I'll be sworn he has the Canonical smirk, and the filthy, clammy palm of a Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Well, most reverend Doctor, pray let us make an end of this fooling.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: With all my soul, Divine, Heavenly Creature, when you please.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: He speaks like a Chaplain indeed.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Why, was there not, soul, Divine, Heavenly, in what he said.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Once more, most impertinent Black-coat, cease your persecution, and let us have a Conclusion of this ridiculous love.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I had forgot, I must sute my Stile to my Coat, or I wear it in vain. Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I have no more patience left, let us make once an end of this troublesome Love, I say.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: So be it, Seraphick Lady, when your Honour shall think it meet, and convenient so to do.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Gad I'm sure none but a Chaplain cou'd speak so, I think.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Let me tell you Sir, this dull trick will not serve your turn, though you delay our marriage, you shall not hinder it.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Far be it from me, Munificent Patroness, to delay your Marriage, I desire nothing more than to marry you presently, which I might do, if you your self wou'd; for my Noble, Good-natur'd and thrice Generous Patron here wou'd not hinder it.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No, poor man, not I faith.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: And now, Madam, let me tell you plainly, no body else shall marry you by Heavens, I'll die first, for I'm sure I shou'd die after it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: How his Love has made him forget his Function, as I have seen it in real Parsons.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: That was spoken like a Chaplain too, now you understand him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Poor man, he takes it hainously to be refus'd; I can't blame him, 'tis putting an indignity upon him not to be suffer'd, but you'l pardon me Madam, it shan't be, he shall marry us, come away, pray Madam.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Hah, ha, he, more ado! 'tis late.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Invincible stupidity, I tell you he wou'd marry me, as your Rival, not as your Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come, come Madam. Pulling her away.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I pray Madam, do not refuse this reverend Divine the honour and satisfaction of marrying you; for I dare say, he has set his heart upon't, good Doctor.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: What can you hope, or design by this?

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l:
I cou'd answer her, a reprieve for a day only, often
revokes a hasty doom; at worst, if she will not take mercy on me, and let me marry her, I have at least the Lovers second pleasure, hindring my Rivals enjoyment, though but for a time.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come Madam, 'tis e'ne twelve a clock, and my Mother charg'd me never to be married out of the Canonical hours; come, come, Lord here's such a deal of modesty, I warrant the first day.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Yes, an't please your Worship, married women shew all their Modesty the first day, because married men shew all their love the first day.

div.stage: Exeunt Sparkish, Alithea, Harcourt, and Lucy.
The Scene changes to a Bed-chamber, where appear Pinchwife, Mrs. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinch.
sp.l: Come tell me, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinch.
sp.l: Lord, han't I told it an hundred times over.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinch.
sp.l: I wou'd try, if in the repetition of the ungrateful tale, I cou'd find her altering it in the least circumstance, for if her story be false, she is so too. Aside.
Come how was't Baggage?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinch.
sp.l: Lord, what pleasure you take to hear it sure!

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinch.
sp.l: No, you take more in telling it I find, but speak how was't?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinch.
sp.l: He carried me up into the house, next to the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So, and you two were only in the room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, for he sent away a youth that was there, for some dryed fruit, and China Oranges.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Did he so? Damn him for it —and for —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: But presently came up the Gentlewoman of the house.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O 'twas well she did, but what did he do whilest the fruit came?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l:
He kiss'd me an hundred times, and told me he fancied he kiss'd my fine Sister, meaning me you know, whom he said he lov'd with all his Soul, and bid me be sure to tell her so, and to desire her to be at her window, by eleven of
the clock this morning, and he wou'd walk under it at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: And he was as good as his word, very punctual, a pox reward him for't. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, and he said if you were not within, he wou'd come up to her, meaning me you know, Bud, still.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —he knew her certainly, but for this consession, I am oblig'd to her simplicity. Aside.
But what you stood very still, when he kiss'd you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes I warrant you, wou'd you have had me discover'd my self?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But you told me, he did some beastliness to you, as you call'd it, what was't?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why, he put —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why he put the tip of his tongue between my lips, and so musl'd me —and I said, I'd bite it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: An eternal canker seize it, for a dog.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, you need not be so angry with him netiher, for to say truth, he has the sweetest breath I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: The Devil —you were satisfied with it then, and wou'd do it again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Not unless he shou'd force me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Force you, changeling! I tell you no woman can be forced.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, but she may sure, by such a one as he, for he's a proper, goodly strong man, 'tis hard, let me tell you, to resist him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
So, 'tis plain she loves him, yet she has not love enough to make her conceal it from me, but the sight of him will increase her aversion for me, and love for him; and that love instruct her how to deceive me, and satisfie him, all Ideot as she is: Love, 'twas he gave women first their craft, their art of deluding; out of natures hands, they came plain, open, silly and fit for slaves, as she and heaven intended 'em; but damn'd Love —Well —I must strangle that little Monster, whilest I can deal with him.
Go fetch Pen, Ink and Paper out of the next room:

sp.speaker: Mrs Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes Bud. Exit Mrs. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why should Women have more invention in love than men? It can only be, because they have more desires, more solliciting passions, more lust, and more of the Devil. Mistriss Pinchwife returns. Aside. Come, Minks, sit down and write.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, dear Bud, but I can't do't very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I wish you cou'd not at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: But what shou'd I write for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I'll have you write a Letter to your Lover.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord, to the fine Gentleman a Letter!

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, to the fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Lord, you do but jeer; sure you jest.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I am not so merry, come write as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What, do you think I am a fool?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: She's afraid I would not dictate any love to him, therefore she's unwilling; but you had best begin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Indeed, and indeed, but I won't, so I won't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Because he's in Town, you may send for him if you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Very well, you wou'd have him brought to you; is it come to this? I say take the pen and write, or you'll provoke me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Lord, what d'ye make a fool of me for? Don't I know that letters are never writ, but from the Countrey to London , and from London into the Countrey; now he's in Town, and I am in Town too; therefore I can't write to him you know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So I am glad it is no worse, she is innocent enough yet Aside.
Yes you may when your Husband bids you write Letters to people that are in Town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O may I so! Then I'm satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come begin —Sir — Dictates.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Shan't I say, Dear Sir? You know one says always something more than bare Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Write as I bid you, or I will write Whore with this Penknife in your Face.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay good Bud—Sir — She writes. Kisses and Embraces —Write

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, why shou'd I say so, you know I told you, he had a sweet breath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Write.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let me but put out, loath'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Write I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well then. Writes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let's see what have you writ?
Though I suffer'd last night your kisses and embraces — Takes the paper, and reads.
Thou impudent creature, where is nauseous and loath'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I can't abide to write such filthy words.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Once more write as I'd have you, and question it not, or I will spoil thy writing with this, I will stab out those eyes that cause my mischief. Holds up the penknife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord, I will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —so —Let's see now! Reads.
Though I suffer'd last night your nauseous, loath'd kisses, and embraces; Go on—Yet I would not have you presume that you shall ever repeat them—So— She writes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I have writ it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: On then —I then conceal'd my self from your knowledge, to avoid your insolencies— She writes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: The same reason now I am out of your hands — She writes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Makes me own to you my unfortunate, though innocent frolick, of being in man's cloths. She writes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: That you may for ever more cease to pursue her, who hates and detests you — She writes on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: So —h — Sighs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What do you sigh? —detests you —as much as she loves her Husband and her Honour —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I vow Husband he'll ne'er believe, I shou'd write such a letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What he'd expect a kinder from you? come now your name only.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What, shan't I say your most faithful, humble Servant till death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, tormenting Fiend; her stile I find wou'd be very soft. Aside.
Come wrap it up now, whilest I go fetch wax and a candle; and write on the back side, for Mr. Horner. Exit Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: For Mr. Horner —So, I am glad he has told me his name; Dear Mr. Horner , but why should I send thee such a Letter, that will vex thee, and make thee angry with me; —well I will not send it —Ay but then my husband will kill me —for I see plainly, he won't let me love Mr. Horner —but what care I for my Husband —I won't so I won't send poor Mr. Horner such a Letter —but then my Husband —But oh —what if I writ at bottom, my Husband made me write it —Ay but then my Husband wou'd see't —Can one have no shift, ah a London woman wou'd have had a hundred presently; stay —what if I shou'd write a Letter, and wrap it up like this, and write upon't too; ay but then my Husband wou'd see't —I don't know what to do —But yet y vads I'll try, so I will — for I will not send this Letter to poor Mr. Horner , come what will on't.

Dear, Sweet Mr. Horner — So — She writes, and repeats what she hath writ. my Husband wou'd have me send you a base, rude, unmannerly Letter —but I won't — so —and wou'd have me forbid you loving me —but I wont — so —and wou'd have me sav to you, I hate you poor Mr. Horner —but I won't tell a lye for him — there —for I'm sure if you and I were
in the Countrey at cards together, — so —I cou'd not help treading on your Toe under the Table— so —or rubbing knees with you and staring in your face, 'till you saw me — very well —and then looking down, and blushing for an hour together— so —but I must make haste before my Husband come; and now he has taught me to write Letters: You shall have longer ones from me, who am Dear, dear, poor dear Mr. Horner , your most Humble Friend, and Servant to command 'till death, Margery Pinchwife.
Stay I must give him a hint at bottom — so —now wrap it up just like t'other — so —now write for Mr. Horner ,— But oh now what shall I do with it? for here comes my Husband. Enter Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I have been detained by a Sparkish Coxcomb, who pretended a visit to me; but I fear 'twas to my Wife. Aside.
What, have you done?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay, ay Bud, just now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let's see't, what d'ye tremble for; what, you wou'd not have it go?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Here —No I must not He opens, and reads the first Letter. give him that, so I had been served if I had given him this. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, where's the Wax and Seal?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Lord, what shall I do now? Nay then I have it — Aside. Snatches the Letter from him, changes it for the other, seals it, and delivers it to him.
Pray let me see't, Lord you think me so errand a fool, I cannot seal a Letter, I will do't, so I will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, I believe you will learn that, and other things too, which I wou'd not have you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: So, han't I done it curiously? I think I have, there's my Letter going to Mr. Horner ; since he'll needs have me send Letters to Folks. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis very well, but I warrant, you wou'd not have it go now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes indeed, but I wou'd, Bud, now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well you are a good Girl then, come let me lock you up in your chamber, 'till I come back; and be sure you come not within three strides of the window, when I am gone; for I have a spye in the street. Exit Mrs. Pinchwife

At least, 'tis fit she think so, if we do pinchwife locks the door. not cheat women, they'll cheat us; and fraud may be justly used with secret enemies, of which a Wife is the most dangerous; and he that has a handsome one to keep, and a Frontier Town, must provide against treachery, rather than open Force —Now I have secur'd all within, I'll deal with the Foe without with false intelligence.

div.stage: The Scene changes to Horner's Lodging.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Well Sir, how fadges the new design; have you not the luck of all your brother Projectors, to deceive only your self at last.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, good Domine Doctor, I deceive you it seems, and others too; for the grave Matrons, and old ridgid Husbands think me as unfit for love, as they are; but their Wives, Sisters and Daughters, know some of 'em better things already.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Already!

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Already, I say; last night I was drunk with half a dozen of your civil persons, as you call 'em, and people of Honour, and so was made free of their Society, and dressing rooms for ever hereafter; and am already come to the privileges of sleeping upon the Pallats, warming Smocks, tying Shooes and Garters, and the like Doctor, already, already Doctor.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: You have made use of your time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
I tell thee, I am now no more interruption to 'em,
when they sing, or talk bawdy, than a little squab French Page, who speaks no English.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: But do civil persons, and women of Honour drink, and sing bawdy Songs?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: O amongst Friends, amongst Friends; for your Bigots in Honour, are just like those in Religion; they fear the eye of the world, more than the eye of Heaven, and think there is no virtue, but railing at vice; and no sin, but giving scandal: They rail at a poor, little, kept Player, and keep themselves some young, modest Pulpit Comedian to be privy to their sins in their Closets, not to tell 'em of them in their Chappels.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Nay, the truth on't is, Priests amongst the women now, have quite got better of us Lay Consessors, Physicians.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And they are rather their Patients, but — Enter my Lady Fidget, looking about her. Now we talk of women of Honour, here comes one, step behind the Screen there, and but observe; if I have not particular privileges, with the women of reputation already, Doctor, already.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Well Horner , am not I a woman of Honour? you see I'm as good as my word.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And you shall see Madam, I'll not be behind hand with you in honour; and I'll be as good as my word too, if you please but to withdraw into the next room.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: But first, my dear Sir, you must promise to have a care of my dear Honour.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: If you talk a word more of your Honour, you'll make me incapacle to wrong it; to talk of Honour in the mysteries of Love, is like talking of Heaven, or the Deity in an operation of Witchcraft, just when you are employing the Devil, it makes the charm impotent.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Nay, fie, let us no be smooty; but you talk of mysteries, and bewitching to me, I don't understand you.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
I tell you Madam, the word money in a Mistresses mouth, at such a nick of time, is not a more disheartening sound
to a younger Brother, than that of Honour to an eager Lover like my self.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: But you can't blame a Lady of my reputation to be chary.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Chary —I have been chary of it already, by the report I have caus'd of my self.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
Horner
sp.l: Nay, Madam, rather than they shall prejudice your Honour, I'll prejudice theirs; and to serve you, I'll lye with 'em all, make the secret their own, and then they'll keep it: I am a Machiavel in love Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: O, no Sir, not that way.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, the Devil take me, if censorious women are to be silenc'd any other way.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: A secret is better kept I hope, by a single person, than a multitude; therefore pray do not trust any body else with it, dear, dear Mr. Horner. Embracing him. Enter Sir Jaspar Fidget.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: How now!

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: O my Husband —prevented —and what's almost as bad, found with my arms about another man — that will appear too much —what shall I say? Aside.
Sir Jaspar come hither, I am trying if Mr. Horner were ticklish, and he's as ticklish as can be, I love to torment the confounded Toad; let you and I tickle him.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: No, your Ladyship will tickle him better without me, I suppose, but is this your buying China, I thought you had been at the China House?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: China-House, that's my Cue, I must take it Aside.

A Pox, can't you keep your impertinent Wives at home? some men are troubled with the Husbands, but I with the
Wives; but I'd have you to know, since I cannot be your Journey-man by night, I will not be your drudge by day, to squire your wife about, and be your man of straw, or scare-crow only to Pyes and Jays; that would be nibling at your forbidden fruit; I shall be shortly the Hackney Gentleman-Usher of the Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Heh, heh, he, poor fellow he's in the right on't faith, to squire women about for other folks, is as ungrateful an employment, as to tell money for other folks; Aside. heh, he, he, ben't angry Horner —

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, 'tis I have more reason to be angry, who am left by you, to go abroad indecently alone; or, what is more indecent, to pin my self upon such ill bred people of your acquaintance, as this is.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nay, pr'ythee what has he done?

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Nay, he has done nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir. Jas.
sp.l: But what d'ye take ill, if he has done nothing?

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah, Faith, I can't but laugh however; why d'ye think the unmannerly toad wou'd not come down to me to the Coach, I was fain to come up to fetch him, or go without him, which I was resolved not to do; for he knows China very well, and has himself very good, but will not let me see it, lest I should beg some; but I will find it out, and have what I came for yet. Exit Lady Fidget, and locks the door, followed by Horner to the door.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Lock the door Madam — Apart to Lady Fidget.

So, she has got into my chamber, and lock'd me out; oh the impertinency of woman-kind! Well Sir Jaspar , plain dealing is a Jewel; if ever you suffer your Wife to trouble me again here, she shall carry you home a pair of Horns, by my Lord Major she shall; though I cannot furnish you my self, you are sure, yet I'll find a way.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Hah, ha, he, at my first coming in, and finding her arms about him, tickling him it seems, I was half jealous, but now I see my folly. Aside.
Heh, he, he, poor Horner.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, though you laugh now, 'twill be my turn e're long: Oh women, more impertinent, more cunning, and more mischievous than their Monkeys, and to me almost as ugly —now is she throwing my things about, and rifling all I have, but I'll get into her the back way, and so rifle her for it —

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Hah, ha, ha, poor angry Horner.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Stay here a little, I'll ferret her out to presently, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Wife, my Lady Fidget , Wife, he is coming into you the back way.

div.stage: Sir Jaspar calls through the door to his Wife, she answers from within.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Let him come, and welcome, which way he will.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: He'll catch you, and use you roughly, and be too strong for you.

sp.speaker: La Fid.
sp.l: Don't you trouble your self, let him if he can.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: This indeed, I cou'd not have believ'd from him, nor any but my own eyes. Enter Mistriss Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Where's this Woman-hater, this Toad, this ugly, greasie, dirty sloven?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: So the women all will have him ugly, methinks he is a comely person; but he wants make his form contemptible to 'em; and 'tis e'en as my Wife said yesterday, talking of him, that a proper handsome Eunuch, was as ridiculous a thing, as a Gigantick Coward.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Sir Jaspar , your Servant, where is the odious Beast?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: He's within in his chamber, with my Wife; she's playing the wag with him.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Is she so, and he's a clownish beast, he'll give her no quarter, he'll play the wag with her again, let me tell you; come, let's go help her —What, the door's lock't?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, my Wife lock't it —

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Did she so, let us break it open then?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: No, no, he'll do her no hurt.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: No —But is there no other way to get into 'em, whither goes this? I will disturb'em. Aside. Exit Squeamish at another door. Enter old Lady Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Where is this Harlotry, this Impudent Baggage, this rambling Tomrigg? O Sir Jaspar , I'm glad to see you here, did you not see my vil'd Grandchild come in hither just now?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Old L. Squeam
sp.l: Ay, but where is she then? where is she? Lord Sir Jaspar I have e'ne ratled my self to pieces in pursuit of her, but can you tell what she makes here, they say below, no woman lodges here.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: No —What does she here then? say if it be not a womans lodging, what makes she here? but are you sure no woman lodges here?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: No, nor no man neither, this is Mr. Horners Lodging.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Is it so are you sure?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: So then there's no hurt in't I hope, but where is he?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: He's in the next room with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Nay if you trust him with your wife, I may with my Biddy, they say he's a merry harmless man now, e'ne as harmless a man as ever came out of Italy with a good voice, and as pretty harmless company for a Lady, as a Snake without his teeth.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, ay poor man. Enter Mrs. Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l:
I can't find 'em —Oh are you here, Grandmother, I follow'd you must know my Lady Fidget hither, 'tis the prettyest lodging, and I have been staring on the prettyest Pictures.
Enter Lady Fidget with a piece of China in her hand, and Horner following.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: And I have been toyling and moyling, for the pretti'st piece of China, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay she has been too hard for me do what I cou'd.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Oh Lord I'le have some China too, good Mr. Hor- ner , don't think to give other people China, and me none, come in with me too.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Upon my honour I have none left now.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Nay, nay I have known you deny your China before now, but you shan't put me off so, come —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: This Lady had the last there.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Yes indeed Madam, to my certain knowledge he has no more left.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: O but it may be he may have some you could not find.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: What d'y think if he had had any left, I would not have had it too, for we women of quality never think we have China enough.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Do not take it ill, I cannot make China for you all, but I will have a Rol-waggon for you too, another time.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Thank you dear Toad. To Horn, aside.

sp.speaker: La Fid.
sp.l: What do you mean by that promise?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Alas she has an innocent, literal understanding. Apart to Lady Fidget.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Poor Mr. Horner , he has enough to doe to please you all, I see.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay Madam, you see how they use me.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Poor Gentleman I pitty you.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I thank you Madam, I could never find pitty, but from such reverend Ladies as you are, he young ones will never spare a man.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Come come, Beast, and go dine with us, for we shall want a man at Hombre after dinner.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: That's all their use of me Madam you see.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Come Sloven, I'le lead you to be sure of you. Pulls him by the Crevat.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Alas poor man how she tuggs him, kiss, kiss her, that's the way to make such nice women quiet.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No Madam, that Remedy is worse than the Torment, they know I dare suffer any thing rather than do it.

sp.speaker: Old La. Speamish
sp.l: Prythee kiss her, and I'le give you her Picture in little, that you admir'd so last night, prythee do.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well nothing but that could bribe me, I love a woman only in Effigie, and good Painting as much as I hate them —I'le do't, for I cou'd adore the Devil well painted. Kisses Mrs. Speamish

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Foh, you filthy Toad, nay now I've done jesting.

sp.speaker: Old L. Speamish
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I told you so.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Foh a kiss of his —

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Has no more hurt in't, than one of my Spaniels.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Nor no more good neither.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: I will now believe any thing he tells me. Behind. Enter Mr. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: O Lord here's a man, Sir Jaspar , my Mask, my Mask, I would not be seen here for the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: What not when I am with you.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, no my honour — let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Oh Grandmother, let us be gone, make hast, make hast, I know not how he may censure us.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Be found in the lodging of any thing like a man, away. Exeunt Sir Jaspar La, Fid. Old La. Speamish Mrs. Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: What's here another Cuckold — he looks like one, and none else sure have any business with him, Behind.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well what brings my dear friend hither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinch.
sp.l: Your impertinency.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: My impertinency — why you Gentlemen that have got handsome Wives, think you have a privilege of saying any thing to your friends, and are as brutish, as if you were our Creditors.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinch
sp.l: No Sir, I'le ne're trust you any way.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But why not, dear Jack , why diffide in me, thou knowst so well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Because I do know you so well.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Han't I been always thy friend honest Jack , always ready to serve thee, in love, or battle, before thou wert married, and am so still.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I believe so you wou'd be my second now indeed.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well then dear Jack , why so unkind, so grum, so strange to me, come prythee kiss me deare Rogue, gad I was always I say, and am still as much thy Servant as —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: As I am yours Sir. What you wou'd send a kiss to my Wife, is that it?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So there 'tis — a man can't shew his friendship to a married man, but presently he talks of his wife to you, prythee let thy Wife alone, and let thee and I be all one, as we were wont, what thou art as shye of my kindness, as a Lumbart-street Alderman of a Courtiers civility at Lockets.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But you are over kind to me, as kind, as if I were your Cuckold already, yet I must confess you ought to be kind and civil to me, since I am so kind, so civil to you, as to bring you this, look you there Sir. Delivers him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinch.
sp.l: Only a Love Letter Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: From whom — how, this is from your Wife — hum — and hum —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Even from my Wife Sir, am I not wondrous kind and civil to you, now too? But you'l not think her so. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ha, is this a trick of his or hers Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: The Gentleman's surpriz'd I find, what you expected a kinder Letter?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No faith not I, how cou'd I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes yes, I'm sure you did, a man so well made as you are must needs be disappointed, if the women declare not their passion at first sight or opportunity.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
But what should this mean? stay the Postscript. Be sure you love me whatsoever my husband says to the contrary, and let him not see this, lest he should come
home, and pinch me, or kill my Squirrel. Reads aside. It seems he knows not what the Letter contains. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come ne're wonder at it so much.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Faith I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Now I think I have deserv'd your infinite friendship, and kindness, and have shewed my self sufficiently an obliging kind friend and husband, am I not so, to bring a Letter from my Wife to her Gallant?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, the Devil take me, art thou, the most obliging, kind friend and husband in the world, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well you may be merry Sir, but in short I must tell you Sir, my honour will suffer no jesting.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What do'st thou mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Does the Letter want a Comment? then know Sir, though I have been so civil a husband, as to bring you a Letter from my Wife, to let you kiss and court her to my face, I will not be a Cuckold Sir, I will not.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Thou art mad with jealousie, I never saw thy Wife in my life, but at the Play yesterday, and I know not if it were she or no, I court her, kiss her!

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I will not be a Cuckold I say, there will be danger in making me a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, wert thou not well cur'd of thy last clap?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I weare a Sword.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: It should be taken from thee, left thou should'st do thy self a mischiefe with it, thou art mad, Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: As mad as I am, and as merry as you are, I must have more reason form you e're we part, I say again though you kiss'd, and courted last night my Wife in man's clothes, as she confesses in her Letter.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ha — Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
