sp.l: Both she and I say you must not design it again, for you have mistaken your woman, as you have done your man.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Oh —I understand something now — Aside. Was that thy Wife? why would'st thou not tell me 'twas she? faith my freedome with her was your fault, not mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Faith so 'twas — Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Fye, I'de never do't to a woman before her husbands face, sure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But I had rather you should do't to my wife before my face, than behind my back, and that you shall never doe.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No —you will hinder me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: If I would not hinder you, you see by her Letter, she wou'd.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well, I must e'ne acquiess then, and be contented with what she writes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I'le assure you 'twas voluntarily writ, I had no hand in't you may believe me.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I do believe thee, faith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: And believe her too, for she's an innocent creature, has no dissembling in her, and so fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Pray however present my humble service to her, and tell her I will obey her Letter to a tittle, and fulfill her desires be what they will, or with what difficulty soever I do't, and you shall be no more jealous of me, I warrant her, and you —

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well then fare you well, and play with any mans honour but mine, kiss any mans wife but mine, and welcome — Exit Mr. Pinch.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: It seems he has not heard the report of you, or does not believe it.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ha, ha, now Doctor what think you?

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Pray let's see the Letter —hum —for — deare —love you —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I wonder how she cou'd contrive it! what say'st thou to't, 'tis an Original.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: So are your Cuckolds too Originals: for they are like no other common Cuckolds, and I will henceforth believe it not impossible for you to Cuckold the Grand Signior amidst his Guards of Eunuchs, that I say —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
And I say for the Letter, 'tis the first love Letter that
ever was without Flames, Darts, Fates, Destinies, Lying and Dissembling in't.

div.stage: Enter Sparkish pulling in Mr. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come back, you are a pretty Brother-in-law, neither go to Church, nor to dinner with your Sister Bride.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: My Sister denies her marriage, and you see is gone away from you dissatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw, upon a foolish scruple, that our Parson was not in lawful Orders, and did not say all the Common Prayer, but 'tis her modesty only I believe, but let women be never so modest the first day, they'l be sure to come to themselves by night, and I shall have enough of her then; in the mean time, Harry Horner, you must dine with me, I keep my wedding at my Aunts in the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Thy wedding, what stale Maid has liv'd to despaire of a husband, or what young one of a Gallant?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: O your Servant Sir —this Gentlemans Sister then —No stale Maid.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I'm sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How comes he so concern'd for her — Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: You sorry for't, why do you know any ill by her?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, I know none but by thee, 'tis for her sake, not yours, and another mans sake that might have hop'd, I thought —

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Another Man, another man, what is his Name?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay since 'tis past he shall be nameless. Poor Harcourt I am sorry thou hast mist her — Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: He seems to be much troubled at the match— Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Prythee tell me —nay you shan't go Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I must of necessity, but I'le come to you to dinner. Exit Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l:
But Harry , what have I a Rival in my Wife already? but withal my heart, for he may be of use to me hereafter, for though my hunger is now my sawce, and I can fall on heartily without, but the time will come, when a Rival will be as
good sawce for a married man to a wife, as an Orange to Veale.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: O thou damn'd Rogue, thou hast set my teeth on edge with thy Orange.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Then let's to dinner, there I was with you againe, come.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But who dines with thee?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: My Friends and Relations, my Brother Pinchwife you see of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No gad, he'l nere let her come amongst us good fellows, your stingy country Coxcomb keeps his wife from his friends, as he does his little Firkin of Ale, for his own drinking, and a Gentleman can't get a smack on't, but his servants, when his back is turn'd broach it at their pleasures, and dust it away, ha, ha, ha, gad I am witty, I think, considering I was married to day, by the world, but come —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, I will not dine with you, unless you can fetch her too.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Pshaw what pleasure can'st thou have with women now, Harry?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: My eyes are not gone, I love a good prospect yet, and will not dine with you, unless she does too, go fetch her therefore, but do not tell her husband, 'tis for my sake.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Well I'le go try what I can do, in the mean time come away to my Aunts lodging, 'tis in the way to Pinch- wifes.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: The poor woman has call'd for aid, and stretch'd forth her hand Doctor, I cannot but help her over the Pale out of the Bryars.

div.stage: The Scene changes to Pinchwifes house.
A Table, Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Well 'tis 'ene so, I have got the London disease, they call Love, I am sick of my Husband, and for my Gallant;
I have heard this distemper, call'd a Feaver, but methinks 'tis liker an Ague, for when I think of my Husband, I tremble and am in a cold sweat, and have inclinations to vomit, but when I think of my Gallant, dear Mr. Horner , my hot fit come, and I am all in a Feaver, indeed &c.amp;c. as in other Feavers, my own Chamber is tedious to me, and would fain be remov'd to his, and then methinks I shou'd be well; ah poor Mr. Horner, well I cannot, will not stay here, therefore I'le make an end of my Letter to him, which shall be a finer Letter than my last, because I have studied it like any thing; O Sick, Sick!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Pinchwife who seeing her writing steales softly behind her, and looking over her shoulder, snatches the paper from her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What writing more Letters?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord Budd, why d'ye fright She offers to run out: he stops her, and reads. me so?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How's this! nay you shall not stir Madam.

Deare, Deare, deare, Mr Horner —very well — I have taught you to write Letters to good purpose —but let's see't. First I am to beg your pardon for my boldness in writing to you, which I'de have you to know, I would not have done, had not you said first you lov'd me so extreamly, which if you doe, you will never suffer me to lye in the arms of another man, whom I loath, nauseate, and detest — Now you can write these filthy words. but what follows — Therefore I hope you will speedily find some way to free me from this unfortunate match, which was never, I assure you, of my choice, but I'm afraid 'tis already too far gone; however if you love me, as I do you, you will try what you can do, but you must help me away before to morrow, or else alass I shall be for ever out of your reach, for I can defer no longer our —our —what is to follow our — speak what? our Journey into The Letter concludes. the Country I suppose —Oh Woman, damnd Woman,
and Love, damn'd Love, their old Tempter, for this is one of his miracles, in a moment, he can make those blind that cou'd see, and those see that were blind, those dumb that could speak, and those prattle who were dumb before, nay what is more than all, make these dow-bak'd, sensless, indocile animals, Women, too hard for us their Politick Lords and Rulers in a moment; But make an end of your Letter, and then I'le make an end of you thus, and all my plagues together. Draws his Sword.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord, O Lord you are such a Passionate Man, Budd. Enter Sparkish.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: How now what's here to doe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: This Fool here now!

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: What drawn upon your Wife? you shou'd never do that but at night in the dark when you can't hurt her, this is my Sister in Law is it not? ay faith e'ne our Pulls aside her Handkercheife. Country Margery, one may know her, come she and you must go dine with me, dinner's ready, come, but where's my Wife, is she not come home yet, where is she?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Making you a Cuckold, 'tis that they all doe, as soon as they can.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: What the Wedding day? no, a Wife that designs to make a Cully of her Husband, will be sure to let him win the first stake of love, by the world, but come they stay dinner for us, come I'le lead down our Margery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: No —Sir go We'l follow you.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: I will not wag without you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: This Coxcomb is a sensible torment to me amidst the greatest in the world.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come, come Madam Margery.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No I'le lead her my way, Leads her to t'other door, and locks her in and returns. what wou'd you treat your friends with mine, for want of your own Wife? I am contented my rage shou'd take breath — Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: I told Horner this.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come now.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Lord, how shye you are of your Wife, but let me tell you Brother, we men of wit have amongst us a saying, that Cuckolding like the small Pox comes with a fear, and you may keep your Wife as much as you will out of danger of infection, but if her constitution incline her to't, she'l have it sooner or later by the world, say they.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What a thing is a Cuckold, that every fool can make him ridiculous — Aside. Well Sir —But let me advise you, now you are come to be concern'd, because you suspect the danger, not to neglect the means to prevent it, especially when the greatest share of the Malady will light upon your own head, for —
How'sere the kind Wife's Belly comes to swell.
The Husband breeds for her, and first is ill

div.stage: Enter Mr. Pinchwife and Mrs. Pinchwife, a Table and Candle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come take the Pen and make an end of the Letter, just as you intended, if you are false in a tittle, I shall soon perceive it, and punish you with this as you deserve, write what was to follow —let's see — Lays his hand on his Sword. You must make haste and help me away before to morrow, or else I shall be for ever out of your reach, for I can defer no longer our — What follows our?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Must all out then Budd? — Mrs. Pinchwife takes the Pen and writes. Look you there then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Let's see —[For I can defer no longer our—
Wedding —Your slighted Alithea ] What's the meaning of this, my Sisters name to't, speak, unriddle

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes indeed Budd

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But why her name to't speak —speak I say

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ay but you'l tell her then again, if you wou'd not tell her again

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I will not, I am stunn'd, my head turns round, speak

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Won't you tell her indeed, and indeed

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, speak I say

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: She'l be angry with me, but I had rather she should be angry with me than you Budd; and to tell you the truth, 'twas she made me write the Letter, and taught me what I should write

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Ha —I thought the stile was somewhat better than her own, but how cou'd she come to you to teach you, since I had lock'd you up alone

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O through the key hole Budd

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But why should she make you write a Letter for her to him, since she can write her self

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why she said because —for I was unwilling to do it

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Because what —because

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Because left Mr. Horner should be cruel and refuse her, or vaine afterwards, and shew the Letter, she might disown it, the hand not being hers

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How's this? ha —then I think I shall come to my self again —This changeling cou'd not invent this lye, but if she cou'd, why should she? she might think I should soon discover it —stay —now I think on't too, Horner said he was sorry she had married Sparkish , and her disowning her marriage to me, makes me think she has evaded it, for Horner's sake, yet why should she take this course, but men in love are fools, women may well be so. — Aside. But hark you Madam, your Sister went out in the morning, and I have not seen her within sinee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: A lack a day she has been crying all day above it seems in a corner

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Where is she, let me speak with her

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord then he'l discover all — Aside. Pray hold Budd, what d'y mean to discover me, she'l know I have told you then, pray Budd let me talk with her first—

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I must speak with her to know whether Horner ever made her any promise; and whether she be married to Sparkish or no

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray dear Budd don't, till I have spoken with her and told her that I have told you all, for she'll kill me else

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Go then and bid her come out to me

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Yes, yes Budd—[mdash ]

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let me see—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I'le go, but she is not within to come to him, I have just got time to know of Lucy her Maid, who first set me on work, what lye I shall tell next, for I am e'ne at my wits end — Exit Mrs. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well I resolve it, Horner shall have her, I'd rather give him my Sister than lend him my Wife, and such an alliance will prevent his pretensions to my Wife sure, —I'le make him of kinn to her, and then he won't care for her

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord Budd I told you what anger you would make me with my Sister

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Won't she come hither

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: No no, alack a day, she's asham'd to look you in the face, and she says if you go in to her, she'l run away down stairs and shamefully go her self to Mr. Horner, who has promis'd her marriage she says, and she will have no other, so she won't—

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Did he so —promise her marriage —then she shall have no other, go tell her so, and if she will come and discourse with me a little concerning the means, I will about it immediately, go — Exit Mrs. Pinchwife
His estate is equal to Sparkish's , and his extraction as much better than his, as his parts are, but my chief reason is, I'd rather be of kin to him by the name of Brother-in-law, than that of Cuckold — Well what says she now

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why she says she would only have you lead her to Horners lodging—with whom she first will discourse the matter before she talk with you, which yet she cannot doe; for alack poor creature, she says she can't so much as look you in the face, therefore she'l come to you in a mask, and you must excuse her if she make you no answer to any question of yours, till you have brought her to Mr. Horner, and if you will not chide her, nor question her, she'l come out to you immediately

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Let her come I will not speak a word to her, nor require a word from her

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Oh I forgot, besides she says, she cannot look you in the face, though through a mask, therefore wou'd desire you to put out the Candle

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I agree to all, let her make Exit Mrs. Pin, puts out the Candle. haste —there 'tis out —My case is something better, I'd rather fight with Horner for not lying with my Sister, than for lying with my Wife, and of the two I had rather find my Sister too forward than my Wife; I expected no other from her free education, as she calls it, and her passion for the Town —well —Wife and Sister are names which make us expect Love and duty, pleasure and comfort, but we find 'em plagues and torments and are equally, though differently troublesome to their keeper; for we have as much a doe to get people to lye with our Sisters, as to keep 'em from lying with our Wives. Enter Mrs. Pinchwife Masked and in Hoods and Scarves, and a night Gown and Petticoat of Alitheas in the dark. What are you come Sister? let us go then —but first let me lock up my Wife, Mrs. Margery where are you

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Here Budd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come hither, that I may lock you up, Locks the door. get you in, Come Sister where are you now?

div.stage: Mrs. Pinchwife gives him her hand, but when he lets her go, she steals softly on t'other side of him, and is lead away by him for his Sister Alithea.
The Scene changes to Horners Lodging. Quack, Horner.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: What all alone, not so much as one of your Cuckolds here, nor one of their Wives! they use to take their turns with you, as if they were to watch you

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Yes it often happens, that a Cuckold is but his Wifes spye, and is more upon family duty, when he is with her gallant abroad hindring his pleasure, than when he is at home with her playing the Gallant, but the hardest duty a married woman imposes upon a lover is, keeping her husband company always

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: And his fondness wearies you almost as soon as hers

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Pox, keeping a Cuckold company after you have had his Wife, is as tiresome as the company of a Country Squire to a witty fellow of the Town, when he has got all his Mony

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: And as at first a man makes a friend of the Husband to get the Wife, so at last you are faine to fall out with the Wife to be rid of the Husband

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, most Cuckold-makers are true Courtiers, when once a poor man has crack'd his credit for 'em, they can't abide to come neer him

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: But at first to draw him in are so sweet, so kind, so dear, just as you are to Pinchwife, but what becomes of that intrigue with his Wife

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Pox he's as surly as an Alderman that has been bit, and since he's so coy, his Wife's kindness is in vain, for she's a silly innocent

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Did she not send you a Letter by him

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
Yes, but that's a riddle I have not yet solv'd —allow the poor creature to be willing, she is silly too, and he
keeps her up so close—

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Yes, so close that he makes her but the more willing, and adds but revenge to her love, which two when met seldome faile of satisfying each other one way or other

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What here's the man we are talking of I think. Enter Mr. Pinchwife leading in his Wife Masqued, Muffled, and in her Sisters Gown.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Pshaw

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Bringing his Wife to you is the next thing to bringing a Love Letter from her

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What means this

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: The last time you know Sir I brought you a love Letter, now you see a Mistress, I think you'l say I am a civil man to you

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay the Devil me will I say thou art the civillest man I ever met with, and I have known some; I fancy, I understand thee now, better than I did the Letter, but hark thee in thy eare—

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nothing but the usual question man, is she sound on thy word

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What you take her for a Wench and me for a Pimp

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Pshaw, wench and Pimp, paw words, I know thou art an honest fellow, and hast a great acquaintance among the Ladies, and perhaps hast made love for me rather than let me make love to thy Wife—

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come Sir, in short, I am for no fooling

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nor I neither, therefore prythee let's see her face presently, make show man, art thou sure I don't know her

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I am sure you doe know her

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Pox why dost thou bring her to me then

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Because she's a Relation of mine

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Is she faith man, then thou art still more civil and obliging, dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Who desir'd me to bring her to you

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Then she is obliging, dear Rogue

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: You'l make her welcome for my sake I hope

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I hope she is handsome enough to make her self wellcome; prythee let her unmask

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Doe you speak to her, she wou'd never be rul'd by me

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Madam — Mrs. Pinchwife whispers to Hor. She says she must speak with me in private, withdraw prythee

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: She's unwilling it seems I shou'd know all her undecent conduct in this business — Aside. Well then Ile leave you together, and hope when I am gone you'l agree, if not you and I shan't agree Sir.—

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: What means the Fool? —if she and I agree 'tis no matter what you and I do. Whispers to Mrs Pin, who makes signs with her hand for him to be gone.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: In the mean time I'le fetch a Parson, and find out Sporkish and disabuse him. You wou'd have me fetch a Parson, would you not, well then —Now I think I am rid of her, and shall have no more trouble with her —Our Sisters and Daughters like Usurers money, are safest, when put out; but our Wifes, like their writings, never safe, but in our Closets under Lock and Key. Exit Mr. Pinchwife Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir Jaspar Fidget Sir is coming up

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Here's the trouble of a Cuckold, now we are talking of, a pox on him, has he not enough to doe to hinder his Wifes sport, but he must other women's too. —Step in here Madam. Exit Mrs. Pinchwife Enter Sir Jaspar

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: My best and dearest Friend

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: The old stile Doctor — Well be short, for I am busie, what would your impertinent Wife have now?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Well guess'd y' faith, for I do come from her

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: to invite me to supper, tell her I can't come, go

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nay, now you are out faith, for my Lady and the whole knot of the virtuous gang, as they call themselves, are resolv'd upon a frolick of coming to you to night in a Masquerade, and are all drest already

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I shan't be at home

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Lord how churlish he is to women —nay prythee don't disappoint 'em, they'l think 'tis my fault, prythee don't, I'le send in the Banquet and the Fiddles, but make no noise on't, for the poor virtuous Rogues would not have it known for the world, that they go a Masquerading, and they would come to no mans Ball, but yours

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well, well —get you gone, and tell 'em if they come, 'twill be at the peril of their honour and yours

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Heh, he, he —we'l trust you for that, farewell — Exit Sir Jaspar

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Doctor anon you too shall be my guest.
But now I'm going to a private feast

div.stage: The Scene changes to the Piazza of Covent Garden.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: But who would have thought a Sparkish with the Letter in his hand. woman could have been false to me, by the world, I could not have thought it

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: You were for giving and taking liberty, she has taken it only Sir, now you find in that Letter, you are a frank person, and so is she you see there

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay if this be her hand —for I never saw it

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis no matter whether that be her hand or no, I am sure this hand at her desire lead her to Mr. Horner, with whom I left her just now, to go fetch a Parson to 'em at their desire too, to deprive you of her for ever, for it seems yours was but a mock marriage

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Indeed she wou'd needs have it that 'twas Harcourt himself in a Parsons habit, that married us, but I'm sure he told me 'twas his Brother Ned

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l:
O there 'tis out and you were deceiv'd not she
for you are such a frank person —but I must be gone— you'l find her at Mr. Horners, goe and believe your eyes. Exit Mr. Pinchwife

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay I'le to her, and call her as many Crocodiles, Syrens, Harpies, and other heathenish names, as a Poet would do a Mistress, who had refus'd to heare his suit, nay more his Verses on her. But stay, is not that she following a Torch at t'other end of the Piazza, and from Horners certainly —'tis so — Enter Alithea following a Torch, and Lucy behind. You are well met Madam though you don't think so; what you have made a short visit to Mr. Horner, but I suppose you'l return to him presently, by that time the Parson can be with him

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Mr. Horner, and the Parson Sir—

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Come Madam no more dissembling, no more jilting for I am no more a frank person

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: How's this

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: So 'twill work I see — Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Cou'd you find out no easie Country Fool to abuse? none but me, a Gentleman of wit and pleasure about the Town, but it was your pride to be too hard for a man of parts, unworthy false woman, false as a friend that lends a man mony to lose, false as dice, who undoe those that trust all they have to 'em

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: He has been a great bubble by his similes as they say — Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: You have been too merry Sir at your wedding dinner sure

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: What d'y mock me too

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Or you have been deluded

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: By you

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Let me understand you

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l:
Have you the confidence, I should call it something else, since you know your guilt, to stand my just reproaches? you did not write an impudent Letter to Mr. Horner, who I find now has club'd with you in deluding me with his aversion for women, that I might not forsooth suspect him for my
Rival

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: D'y think the Gentleman can be jealous now Madam — Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: I write a Letter to Mr. Horner

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Nay Madam, do not deny it, your Brother shew'd it me just now, and told likewise he left you at Horners lodging to fetch a Parson to marry you to him, and I wish you joy Madam, joy, joy, and to him too much joy, and to my self more joy for not marrying you

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: So I find my Brother would break off the match, and I can consent to't, since I see this Gentleman can be made jealous. Aside. O Lucy, by his rude usage and jealousie, he makes me almost afraid I am married to him, art thou sure 'twas harcourt himself and no Parson that married us

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: No Madam I thank you, I suppose that was a contrivance too of Mr. Horners and yours, to make Harcourt play the Parson, but I would as little as you have him [one now, do not for the world, for shall I tell you another truth, I never had any passion for you, 'till now, for now I hate you, 'tis true I might have married your portion, as other men of parts of the Town do sometimes, and so your Servant, and to shew my unconcernedness, I'le come to your wedding, and resign you with as much joy as I would a stale wench to a new Cully nay with as much joy, as I would after the first night, if I had been married to you, there's for you, and so your Servant, Servant. Exit Sparkish

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: How was I deceiv'd in a man

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: You'l believe then a fool may be made jealous now? for that easiness in him that suffers him to be led by a Wife, will likewise permit him to be perswaded against her by others

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l:
But marry Mr. Horner, my brother does not intend it sure; if I thought he did, I would take thy advice, and Mr. Harcourt for my Husband, and now I wish, that if there be any over-wise woman of the Town, who like my would marry
a fool, for fortune, liberty, or title, first that her husband may love Play, and be a Cully to all the Town, but her, and suffer none but fortune to be mistress of his purse, then if for liberty, that he may send her into the Country under the conduct of some housewifely mother-in law; and of for title, may the world give 'em none but that of Cuckold

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And for her greater curse Madam, may he not deserve it

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Away impertinent —is not this my old Lady Lanterlus?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Yes Madam. Aside. And here I hope we shall find Mr. Harcourt —

div.stage: The Scene changes again to Horner's Lodging. Horner, Lady Fidget, Mrs. Daynty Fidget, Mrs. Squeamish, a Table, Banquet, and Bottles.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: A Pox they are come too soon —before I have sent back my new —Mistress, all I have now to do, is to lock her in, that they may not see her — Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: That we may be sure of our wellcome, we have brought our entertainment with us, and are resolv'd to treat thee, dear Toad

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: And that we may be merry to purpose, have left they should chance to interrupt us

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Let us sit then

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: First that you may be private, let me lock this door, and that, and I'le wait upon you presently

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No Sir, shut 'em only and your lips for ever, for we must trust you as much as our women

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: You know all vanity's kill'd in me, I have no occasion for talking.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Now Ladies, supposing we had drank each of us our two Bottles, let us speak the truth of our hearts.

sp.speaker: Dainty and Squeamish
sp.l: Agreed

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: By this brimmer, for truth is no where else to be found. Not in thy heart false man. Aside to Horner

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: You have found me a true man I'm sure. Aside to Lady Fidget

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Not every way — Aside to Horner But let us sit and be merry.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget sings.
sp.l: I
Why should our damn'd Tyrants oblige us to live.
On the pittance of Pleasure which they only give.
We must not rejoyce,
With Wine and with noise.
In vaine we must wake in a dull bed alone.
Whilst to our warm Rival the Bottle, they're gone.
Then lay aside charms,
And take up these arms.*The Glasses. [Wycherley's note.]
'Tis Wine only gives 'em their Courage and Wit,
Because we live sober to men we submit.
If for Beauties you'd pass.
Take a lick of the Glass.
'Twill mend your complexions, and when they are gone,
The best red we have is the red of the Grape.
Then Sister lay't on.
And dam a good shape.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Dear Brimmer, well in token of our openness and plain dealing, let us throw our Masques over our heads

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So 'twill come to the Glasses anon

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: Lovely Brimmer, let me enjoy him first

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, I never part with a Gallant, till I've try'd him. Dear Brimmer that mak'st our Husbands short sighted.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: And our bashful gallants bold

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: And for want of a Gallant, the Butler lovely in our eyes, drink Eunuch

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Drink thou representative of a Husband, damn a Husband

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: And as it were a Husband, an old keeper

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: And an old Grandmother

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And an English Bawd, and a French Chirurgion

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Ay we have all reason to curse 'em

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: For my sake Ladies

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, for our own, for the first spoils all young gallants industry

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: And the others art makes 'em bold only with common women

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: And rather run the hazard of the vile distemper amongst them, than of a denial amongst us

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: The filthy Toads chuse Mistresses now, as they do Stuffs, for having been fancy'd and worn by others

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: For being common and cheap

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Whilst women of quality, like the richest Stuffs, lye untumbled, and unask'd for

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay neat, and cheap, and new often they think best

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: No Sir, the Beasts will be known by a Mistriss longer than by a suit

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: And 'tis not for cheapness neither

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, for the vain fopps will take up Druggers, and embroider 'em, but I wonder at the depraved appetites of witty men, they use to be out of the common road, and hate imitation, pray tell me beast, when you were a man, why you rather chose to club with a multitude in a common house, for an entertainment, than to be the only guest at a good Table

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why faith ceremony and expectation are unsufferable to those that are sharp bent, people always eat with the best stomach at an ordinary, where every man is snatching for the best bit.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Though he get a cut over the fingers —but I have heard people eat most heartily of another man's meat, that is, what they do not pay for

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: When they are sure of their wellcome and freedome, for ceremony in love and eating, is as ridiculous as in sighting, falling on briskly is all should be done in those occasions

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Well then let me tell you Sir, there is no where more freedome than in our houses, and we take freedom from a young person as a sign of good breeding, and a person may be as free as he pleases with us, as frolick, as a gamesome, as wild as he will

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Han't I heard you all declaim against wild men

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Yes, but for all that, we think wildness in a man, as desireable a quality, as in a Duck, or Rabbet; a tame man, foh

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I Know not, but your Reputations frightned me, as much as your Faces invited me

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Our Reputation, Lord! Why should you not think, that we women make use of our Reputation, as you men of yours, only to deceive the world with less suspicion; our virtue is like the State-man's Religion, the Quakers Word, the Gamesters Oath, and the Great Man's Honour, but to cheat those that trust us

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: And that Demureness, Coyness, and Modesty, that you see in our Faces in the Boxes at Plays, is as much a sign of a kind woman, as a Vizard-mask in the Pit

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: For I assure you, women are least mask'd, when they have the Velvet Vizard on

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: You wou'd have found us modest women in our denyals only

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: Our Bashfulness is only the reflection of the Men's

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: We blush, when they ae shame-fac'd

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I beg your pardon Ladies, I was deceiv'd in you devilishly, but why, that mighty pretence to Honour

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l:
We have told you; but sometimess 'twas for the
same reason you men pretend business often, to avoid ill company, to enjoy the better, and more privately those you love.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: But why, wou'd you ne'er give a Friend a wink then?

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Faith, your Reputation frightned us as much, as ours did you, you were so notoriously lewd.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And you so seemingly honest.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Was that all that deterr'd you?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And so expensive —you allow freedom you say.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: That I was afraid of losing my little money, as well as my little time, both which my other pleasures required.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Money, foh —you talk like a little fellow now, do such as we expect money?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I beg your pardon, Madam, I must confess, I have heard that great Ladies, like great Merchants, set but the higher prizes upon what they have, because they are not in necessity of taking the first offer.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Such as we, make sale of our hearts?

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: We brib'd for our Love? Foh.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: With your pardon, Ladies, I know, like great men in Offices, you seem to exact flattery and attendance only from your Followers, but you have receivers about you, and such fees to pay, a man is afraid to pass your Grants; besides we must let you win at Cards, or we lose your hearts; and if you make an assignation, 'tis at a Goldsmiths, Jewellers, or China house, where for your Honour, you deposit to him, he must pawn his, to the punctual Citt, and so paying for what you take up, pays for what he takes up.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Wou'd you not have us assur'd of our Gallants Love?

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: For Love is better known by Liberality, than by Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l:
For one may be dissembled, the other not—but my Jealousie can be no longer dissembled, and they are telling ripe: Aside.
Come here's to our Gallants in waiting, whom we must name, and I'll begin, this is my false Rogue. Claps him on the back.

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So all will out now —

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: Did you not tell me, 'twas for my sake only, you reported your self no man? Aside to Horner.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: Oh Wretch! did you not swear to me, 'twas for my Love, and Honour, you pass'd for that thing you do? Aside to Horner.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Come, speak Ladies, this is my false Villain.

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: And mine too.

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Well then, you are all three my false Rogues too, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Well then, there's no remedy, Sister Sharers, let us not fall out, but have a care of our Honour; though we get no Presents, no Jewels of him, we are savers of our Honour, the Jewel of most value and use, which shines yet to the world unsuspected, though it be counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Nay, and is e'en as good, as if it were true, provided the world think so; for Honour, like Beauty now, only depends on the opinion of others.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Well Harry Common, I hope you can be true to three, swear, but 'tis no purpose, to require your Oath; for you are as often forsworn, as you swear to new women.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Come, faith Madam, let us e'en pardon one another, for all the difference I find betwixt we men, and you women, we forswear our selves at the beginning of an Amour, you, as long as it lasts. Enter Sir Jaspar Fidget, and old Lady Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Oh my Lady Fidget , was this your cunning, to come to Mr. Horner without me; but you have been no where else I hope.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: No, Sir Jaspar

sp.speaker: Old Lady Squeamish
sp.l: And you came straight hither Biddy.

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: Yes indeed, Lady Grandmother.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well, I knew when once they were throughly acquainted with poor Horner, they'd ne'er be from him; you may let her masquerade it with my Wife, and Horner, and I warrant her Reputation safe. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: O Sir, here's the Gentleman come, whom you bid me not suffer to come up, without giving you notice, with a Lady too, and other Gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Do you all go in there, whil'st I send 'em away, and Boy, do you desire 'em to stay below 'til I come, which shall be immediately. Exeunt Sir Jaspar, Old Lady Squeamish, Lady Fidget, Mistriss Dainty, Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes Sir. Exit. Exit Horner at t'other door, and returns with Mistriss Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: You wou'd not take my advice to be gone home, before your Husband came back, he'll now discover all, yet pray my Dearest be perswaded to go home, and leave the rest to my management, I'll let you down the back way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: I don't know the way home, so I don't.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: My man shall wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: No, don't you believe, that I'll go at all; what are you weary of me already?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No my life, 'tis that I may love you long, 'tis to secure my love, and your Reputation with your husband, he'll never receive you again else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What care I, d'ye think to frighten me with that? I don't intend to go to him again; you shall be my Husband now.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I cannot be your Husband, Dearest, since you are married to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O wou'd you make me believe that —don't I see every day at London here, women leave their first Husbands, and go, and live with other mens their Wives, pish, pshaw, you'd make me angry, but that I love you so mainly.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: So, they are coming up —In again, Exit Mistris Pinchwife. in, I hear 'em: Well, a silly Mistriss, is like a weak place, soon got, soon lost a man has scarce time for plunder; she betrays her Husband, first to her Gallant, and then her Gallant, to her Husband. Enter Pinchwife, Alithea, Harcourt, Sparkish, Lucy, and a Parson.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come Madam, 'tis not the sudden change of your dress, the confidence of your asseverations, and your false witness there, shall perswade me, I did not bring you hither, just now; here's my witness, who cannot deny it, since you must be confronted —Mr. Horner, did not I bring this Lady to you just now?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Now must I wrong one woman for anothers sake, but that's no new thing with me; for in these cases I am still on the criminal's side, against the innocent. Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Pray, speak Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: It must be so —I must be impudent, and try my luck, impudence uses to be too hard for truth. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What, you are studying an evasion, or excuse for her, speak Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: It must be so —I must be impudent, and try my luck, impudence uses to be too hard for truth. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What, you are studying an evasion, or excuse for her, speak Sir.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No faith, I am something backward only, to speak in womens affairs or disputes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: She bids you speak.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Ay, pray Sir do, pray satisfie him,

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Then truly, you did bring that Lady to me just now,

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: O ho —

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: How Sir —

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: How, Horner!

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: What mean you Sir, I always took you for a man of Honour?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Ay, so much a man of Honour, that I must save my Mistriss, I thank you, come what will on't. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: So if I had had her, she'd have made me believe, the Moon had been made of a Christmans pye.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Now cou'd I speak, if I durst, and solve the Riddle, who am the Author of it. Aside.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: O unfortunate Woman! a combination against my Honour, which most concerns me now, because you share in my disgrace, Sir, and it is your censure which I must now suffer, that troubles me, not theirs.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Madam, then have no trouble, you shall now see 'tis possible for me to love too, without being jealous, I will not only believe your innocence my self, but make all the world believe it — Horner I must now be concern'd for this Ladies Honour. Apart to Horner.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And I must be concern'd for a Ladies Honour too.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: This Lady has her Honour, and I will protect it.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: My Lady has not her Honour, but has given it me to keep, and will preserve it.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: I wou'd not have you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: What's the matter with 'em all. Mistress Pinchwife peeping in behind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Come, come, Mr. Horner, no more disputing. here's the Parson, I brought him not in vain.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No Sir, I'll employ him, if this Lady please.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: How, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ay, what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Why, I have resign'd your Sister to him, he has my consent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But he has not mine Sir, a womans injur'd Honour, no more than a man's, can be repair'd or satisfied by any, but him that first wrong'd it; and you shall marry her presently, or — Lays his hand on his Sword. Enter to them Mistress Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: O Lord, they'll kill poor Mr. Horner, besides he shan't marry her, whilest I stand by, and look on, I'll not lose my second Husband so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: What do I see.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: My Sister in my cloaths!

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Nay, pray now don't quarrel about finding work
for the Parson, he shall marry me to Mr. Horner; for now I believe, you have enough of me. To Mr. Pinchwife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Damn'd, damn'd loving Changeling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray Sister, pardon me for telling so many lyes of you.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I suppose the Riddle is plain now.

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.l: No, that must be my work, good Sir, hear me. Kneels to Mr. Pinchwife, who stands doggedly, with his hat over his eyes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I will never hear woman again, but make 'em all silent, thus — Offers to draw upon his Wife.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: No, that must not be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: You then shall go first, 'tis all one to me. Offers to draw on Horstopt by Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: Hold — Enter Sir Jaspar Fidget, Lady Fidget, Lady Squeamish, Mrs. Dainty Fidget, Mrs. Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: What's the matter, what's the matter, pray what's the matter Sir, I beseech you communicate Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Why my Wife has communicated Sir, as your Wife may have done too Sir, if she knows him Sir —

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Pshaw, with him, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: D'ye mock me Sir, a Cuckold is a kind of a wild Beast, have a care Sir —

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: No sure, you mock me Sir —he cuckold you! it can't be, ha, ha, he, why I'll tell you Sir. Offers to whisper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I tell you again, he has whor'd my Wife, and yours too, if he knows her, and all the women he comes near; 'tis not his dissembling, his hypocrisie can wheedle me.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: How does he dissemble, is he a Hypocrite? nay then —how —Wife —Sister is he an Hypocrite?

sp.speaker: Old Lady Squeamish
sp.l: An Hypocrite, a dissembler, speak young Harlotry, speak how?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nay then —O my head too —O thou libinous Lady!

sp.speaker: Old La. Speamish
sp.l: O thou Harloting, Harlotry, hast thou don't then?

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Speak good Horner, art thou a dissembler, a Rogue? hast thou —

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Soh —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I'll fetch you off, and her too, if she will but hold her tongue. Apart to Horner

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Canst thou? I'll give thee — Apart to Lucy

sp.speaker: Lucy to Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Pray have but patience to hear me Sir, who am the unfortunate cause of all this confusion, your Wife is innocent, I only culpable; for I put her upon telling you all these lyes, concerning my Mistress, in order to breaking off the match, betweem Mr. Sparkish and her, to make way for Mr. Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: Did you so eternal Rotten-tooth, then it seems my Mistress was not false to me, I was only deceiv'd by you, brother that shou'd have been, now an of conduct, who is a frank person now, to bring your Wife to her Lover — ha —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: I assure you Sir, she came not to Mr. Horner out of love, for she loves him no more —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Hold, I told lyes for you, but you shall tell none for me, for I do love Mr. Horner with all my soul, and no body shall say me nay; pray don't you go to make poor Mr. Horner believe to the contrary, 'tis spitefully done of you, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Peace, Dear Ideot. Aside to Mrs. Pinchwife

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: Nay, I will not peace.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Not 'til I make you. Enter Dorilant, Quack.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Horner your Servant, I am the Doctors Guest, he must excuse our intrusion.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: But what's the matter Gentlemen, for Heavens sake, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l:
Oh 'tis well you are come—'tis a censorious world we live in, you may have brought me a reprieve, or else I
had died for a crime, I never committed, and these innocent Ladies had suffer'd with me, therefore pray satisfie these worthy, honourable, jealous Gentlemen —that — Whispers.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: O I understand you, is that all —Sir Jaspar, by heavens and upon the word of a Physician Sir, — Whispers to Sir Jasper.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Nay I do believe you truly —pardon me my virtuous Lady, and dear of honour.

sp.speaker: Old Lady Squeamish
sp.l: What then all's right again.

sp.speaker: Sir Jaspar
sp.l: Ay, ay, and now let us satisfie him too. They whisper with Mr. Pinchwife

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: An Eunuch! pray no fooling with me.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: I'le bring half the Chirurgions in Town to swear it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: They —they'l sweare a man that bled to death through his wounds died of an Apoplexy.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Pray hear me Sir —why all the Town has heard the report of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But does all the Town believe it.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Pray inquire a little, and first of all these.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: I'm sure when I left the Town he was the lewdest fellow in't.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: I tell you Sir he has been in France since, pray ask but these Ladies and Gentlemen, your friend Mr. Dorilant, Gentlemen and Ladies, han't you all heard the late sad report of poor Mr. Horner.

sp.speaker: All Ladies
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: Why thou jealous Fool do'st thou doubt it, he's an errant French Capon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: 'Tis false Sir, you shall not disparage poor Mr. Horner, for to my certain knowledge —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: O hold —

sp.speaker: Speamish
sp.l: Stop her mouth — Aside to Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l: Upon my honour Sir, 'tis as true. To Pinchwife

sp.speaker: Dainty
sp.l: D'y think we would have been seen in his company —

sp.speaker: Squeamish
sp.l: Trust our unspotted reputations with him!

sp.speaker: Lady Fidget
sp.l:
This you get, and we too, by trusting your
secret to a fool — Aside to Hor.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Peace Madam, —well Doctor is not this a good design that carryes a man on unsuspected, and brings him off safe. — Aside to Quack.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: Well, if this were true, but my Wife — Aside Dorilant whispers with Mrs. Pinchwife

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: Come Brother your Wife is yet innocent you see, but have a care of too strong an imagination, least like an overconcern'd timerous Gamester by fancying an unlucky cast it should come, Women and Fortune are truest still to those that trust 'em.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: And any wild thing grows but the more fierce and hungry for being kept up, and more dangerous to the Keeper.

sp.speaker: Alithea
sp.l: There's doctrine for all Husbands Mr. Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harcourt
sp.l: I edifie Madam so much, that I am impatient till I am one.

sp.speaker: Dorilant
sp.l: And I edifie so much by example I will never be one.

sp.speaker: Sparkish
sp.l: And because I will not disparage my parts I'le ne're be one.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: And I alass can't be one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: But I must be one —against my will to a Country-Wife, with a Country murrain to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l: And I must be a Country Wife still too I find, for I can't like a City one, be rid of my musty Husband and doe what I list. Aside.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Now Sir I must pronounce your Wife Innocent, though I blush whilst I do it, and I am the only man by her now expos'd to shame, which I will straight drown in Wine, as you shall you suspition, and the Ladies troubles we'l divert with a Ballet, Doctor where are your Maskers.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.l: Indeed she's Innocent Sir, I am her witness, and her end of coming out was but to see her Sisters Wedding, and what she has said to your face of her love to Mr. Horner was but the usual innocent revenge on a Husbands jealousie, was it not Madam speak —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pinchwife
sp.l:
Since you'l have me tell more lyes — Aside to Lucy and Horner.
Yes indeed Budd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pinchwife
sp.l: For my own sake fain I wou'd all believe.
Cuckolds like Lovers shou'd themselves deceive.
But — sighs
His honour is least safe, (too late I find)
Who trusts it with a foolish Wife or Friend.

sp.speaker: Horner
sp.l: Vain Fopps, but court, and dress, and keep a puther,
To pass for Womens men, with one another.
But he who aimes by women to be priz'd,
First by the men you see must be despis'd.
Now you the Vigorous, who dayly here
O're Vizard-Mask, in publick domineer,
And what you'd doe to her if in Place where;
Nay have the confidence, to cry come out,
Yet when she says lead on, you are not stout;
But to your well-drest Brother straight turn round
And cry, Pox on her Ned, she can't be sound:
Then slink away, a fresh one to ingage,
With so much seeming heat and ioving Rage,
You'd frighten listning Actress on the Stage:
Till she at last seen you huffing come,
And talk of keeping in the Tyreing-Room,
Yet cannot be provok'd to lead her home:
Next you Fallstaffs of fifty, who beset
Your Buckram Maidenheads, which your friends get;
And whilst to them, you of atchievements boast,
They share the booty, and laugh at your cost,
In fine, you Essens't Boyes, both Old and Young,
Who wou'd be thought so eager, brisk, and strong,
Yet do the Ladies, not their Husbands, wrong:
Whose Purses for your manhood make excuse,
And keep your Flanders Mares for shew, not use;
Encourag'd by our Womans Man to day,
A Horners part may vainly think to Play;
And may Intreagues so bashfully disown
That they may doubted be by few or none,
May kiss the Cards at Picquet, Hombre, —Lu,
And so be thought to kiss the Lady too;
But Gallants, have a care faith, what you do.
The World, which to no man his due will give,
You by experience know you can deceive,
And men may still believe you Vigorous,
But then we Women, —there's no cous'ning us.
